word: a

def: used before countable or singular nouns referring to people or things that have not already been mentioned
ex: a man/horse/unit 
ex: an aunt/egg/hour/X-ray 
ex: I can only carry two at a time
ex: There's a visitor for you
ex: She's a friend of my father's (= one of my father's friends)

def: used before uncountable nouns when these have an adjective in front of them, or phrase following them
ex: a good knowledge of French 
ex: a sadness that won't go away3

def: any; every
ex: A lion is a dangerous animal

def: used to show that someone or something is a member of a group or profession
ex: Their new car's a BMW
ex: She's a Buddhist
ex: He's a teacher
ex: Is that a Monet (= a painting by Monet)?5

def: used in front of two nouns that are seen as a single unit
ex: a knife and fork6

def: used instead of 
ex: A thousand people were there

def: used when talking about prices, quantities, and rates
ex: They cost 50 cents a pound
ex: I can type 50 words a minute
ex: He was driving at 50 miles an hour

def: a person like someone
ex: He's a little Shaq

def: used before someone's name to show that the speaker does not know the person
ex: There's a Mrs

def: used before the names of days of the week to talk about one particular day
ex: She died on a Tuesday

-----

word: abandon

def: to leave someone, especially someone you are responsible for, with no intention of returning
ex: The baby had been abandoned by its mother
ex: People often simply abandon their pets when they go on vacation

def: to leave a thing or place, especially because it is impossible or dangerous to stay
ex: abandon something 
ex: Snow forced many drivers to abandon their vehicles
ex: He gave the order to abandon ship (= to leave the ship because it was sinking)
ex: abandon something to somebody/something 
ex: They had to abandon their lands to the invading forces

def: to stop supporting or helping someone; to stop believing in something
ex: abandon somebody 
ex: The country abandoned its political leaders after the war
ex: abandon something 
ex: By 1930 he had abandoned his Marxist principles
ex: abandon something 

def: to stop doing something, especially before it is finished; to stop having something
ex: They abandoned the game because of rain
ex: She abandoned hope of any reconciliation
ex: We had to abandon any further attempt at negotiation
ex: abandon yourself to something (literary) 

def: to feel an emotion so strongly that you can feel nothing else
ex: He abandoned himself to despair

-----

word: abandoned

def: left and not wanted, not used, or no longer needed
ex: an abandoned car/house 
ex: The child was found abandoned but unharmed
ex: There was an abandoned grocery cart in the middle of the road

def: (of people or their behavior) wild; not following accepted standards

-----

word: ability

def: the fact that someone or something is able to do something
ex: The system has the ability to run more than one program at the same time
ex: Everyone has the right to good medical care regardless of their ability to pay
ex: A gentle form of exercise will increase your ability to relax

def: a level of skill or intelligence
ex: Almost everyone has some musical ability
ex: He was a man of extraordinary abilities
ex: students of mixed abilities 
ex: A woman of her ability will easily find a job
ex: I try to do my job to the best of my ability (= as well as I can)

-----

word: able

def: to have the skill, intelligence, opportunity, etc. needed to do something
ex: You must be able to speak French for this job
ex: A viral illness left her barely able to walk
ex: I didn't feel able to disagree with him
ex: Will you be able to come? opposite unable Grammarcan / could / be able to / manageCan is used to say that somebody knows how to do something:
ex: Can you play the piano?It is also used with verbs of seeing, noticing, etc:
ex: I can hear someone calling, and with passive infinitives:
ex: The DVD can be found online
ex: Can you/Are you able to come on Saturday?You use be able to to form the future and perfect tenses and the infinitive:
ex: Youll be able to get a taxi outside the station
ex: I havent been able to get much work done today
ex: Shed love to be able to play the piano
ex: Our daughter could walk when she was nine months old
ex: I was able to/managed to find some useful books in the library
ex: We werent able to/didnt manage to/couldnt get there in time
ex: I could see there was something wrong
ex: I could have won the game but decided to let him win instead

def: intelligent; good at something
ex: the ablest student in the class 
ex: We aim to help the less able in society to lead an independent life

-----

word: about

def: a little more or less than; a little before or after
ex: It costs about $10
ex: They waited (for) about an hour
ex: He arrived (at) about ten

def: nearly; very close to
ex: I'm just about ready
ex: This is about the best we can hope for

def: facing the opposite direction
ex: He brought the ship about

-----

word: above

def: at or to a higher place or position than something or someone
ex: The water came above our knees
ex: We were flying above the clouds
ex: the people in the apartment above mine 
ex: A captain in the navy ranks above a captain in the army
ex: They finished the year six places above their local rivals

def: more than something; greater in number, level, or age than someone or something
ex: Inflation is above 6%
ex: Temperatures have been above average
ex: We cannot accept children above the age of 10

def: of greater importance or of higher quality than someone or something
ex: I rate her above most other players of her age

def: too good or too honest to do something
ex: She's not above lying when it gets her out of trouble
ex: He's above suspicion (= he is completely trusted)

def: louder or clearer than another sound
ex: I couldn't hear her above the noise of the traffic
ex: They built a new room above/over the garage
ex: They jumped over the stream
ex: He put a blanket over the sleeping child
ex: 2,000 feet above sea level 
ex: Temperatures will not rise above freezing tonight
ex: Hes over 50
ex: It costs over $100
ex: We waited over 2 hours

-----

word: abroad

def: in or to a foreign country
ex: to be/go/travel/live abroad 
ex: She worked abroad for a year
ex: He was famous, both at home and abroad (= in his own country and in other countries)

def: being talked about or felt by many people
ex: There was news abroad that a change was coming

def: outside; outdoors

word: absence

def: the fact of someone being away from a place where they are usually expected to be; the occasion or period of time when someone is away
ex: The decision was made in my absence (= while I was not there)
ex: We did not receive any news during his long absence
ex: absence from 
ex: absence from work 
ex: repeated absences from school see also leave2[uncountable] 

def: the fact of someone or something not existing or not being available; a lack of something
ex: The case was dismissed in the absence of any definite proof
ex: the absence of any women on the board of directors opposite presenceIdioms absence makes the heart grow fonder (saying)

word: absent

def: not in a place because of illness, etc.
ex: to be absent from school opposite present2
ex: absent (from something) 

def: not present in something
ex: Love was totally absent from his childhood

def: showing that you are not really looking at or thinking about what is happening around you
ex: an absent expression see also absentlyCheck pronunciation: absent

word: absolute

def: total and complete
ex: a class for absolute beginners 
ex: absolute confidence/trust/silence/truth 
ex: You're wrong, she said with absolute certainty
ex: Around them the darkness was absolute, the silence oppressive

def: used, especially in spoken English, to give emphasis to what you are saying
ex: There's absolute garbage on television tonight
ex: He must earn an absolute fortune
ex: 110 MB is the absolute minimum you need to install the program
ex: What an absolute idiot I've been!3

def: definite and without any doubt or confusion
ex: There was no absolute proof
ex: He taught us that the laws of physics were absolute
ex: The divorce became absolute last week

def: not limited or restricted
ex: absolute power/authority 
ex: an absolute ruler/monarchy (= one with no limit to their power)5

def: existing or measured independently and not in relation to something else
ex: Although prices are falling in absolute terms, energy is still expensive
ex: Beauty cannot be measured by any absolute standard

-----

word: absolutely

def: used to emphasize that something is completely true
ex: You're absolutely right
ex: He made it absolutely clear
ex: I'm not absolutely certain I posted it
ex: It was absolutely pouring with rain

def: used to emphasize something negative
ex: She did absolutely no work
ex: There's absolutely nothing more the doctors can do

def: used with adjectives or verbs that express strong feelings or extreme qualities to mean extremely
ex: I was absolutely furious with him
ex: She absolutely adores you
ex: He's an absolutely fantastic cook

def: used to emphasize that you agree with someone, or to give someone permission to do something
ex: They could have told us, couldn't they? Absolutely! 
ex: Can we leave a little early? Absolutely!5absolutely not 

def: used to emphasize that you strongly disagree with someone, or to refuse permission
ex: Was it any good? No, absolutely not

ex: The lotion is easily absorbed into the skin

ex: absorb something 
ex: The country simply cannot absorb this influx of refugees
ex: absorb something into something 
ex: The surrounding small towns have been absorbed into the city
ex: absorb something

ex: It's a lot of information to absorb all at once
ex: It took me several days to absorb the fact of her death
ex: They spent a week in Paris just absorbing the atmosphere
ex: absorb somebody 

def: to interest someone very much so that they pay no attention to anything else
ex: This work had absorbed him for several years
ex: absorb something 

def: to take in and keep heat, light, energy, etc. instead of reflecting it
ex: Black walls absorb a lot of heat during the day
ex: absorb something 

def: to reduce the effect of a blow, hit, etc.
ex: This tennis racket absorbs shock on impact
ex: The bats have graphite shafts that absorb the vibration
ex: absorb something

ex: The new proposals would absorb $80 billion of the federal budget
ex: absorb something 

def: to deal with changes, effects, costs, etc.

word: actual

def: used to emphasize something that is real or exists in fact
ex: What were his actual words? 
ex: The actual cost was higher than we expected
ex: James looks younger than his wife but in actual fact (= really) he is five years older

def: used to emphasize the most important part of something
ex: The wedding preparations take weeks but the actual ceremony takes less than an hour
ex: I need the actual figures, not an estimate
ex: How long have you been in your present job?Current also means existing or happening now, but can suggest that the situation is temporary:
ex: The factory cannot continue its current level of production

-----

word: actually

def: used in speaking to emphasize a fact or a comment, or that something is really true
ex: What did she actually say? 
ex: It's not actually raining now
ex: That's the only reason I'm actually going
ex: There are lots of people there who can actually help you
ex: I didn't want to say anything without actually reading the letter first

def: used to show a contrast between what is true and what someone believes, and to show surprise about this contrast
ex: It was actually great fun after all
ex: The food was not actually all that expensive
ex: Our turnover actually increased last year

def: used to correct someone in a polite way
ex: We're not American, actually
ex: Actually, it would be much more sensible to do it later
ex: They're not married, actually

def: used to get someone's attention, to introduce a new topic, or to say something that someone may not like, in a polite way
ex: Actually, I'll be a little late getting home
ex: Actually, I'm busy at the momentcan I call you back? Which Word?actual / current / presentActual does not mean current or present
ex: I need the actual figures, not an estimate
ex: How long have you been in your present job?Current also means existing or happening now, but can suggest that the situation is temporary:
ex: The factory cannot continue its current level of production

-----

word: ad

-----

word: adapt

def: to change something in order to make it suitable for a new use or situation
ex: adapt something 
ex: These styles can be adapted to suit individual tastes
ex: adapt something for something 
ex: Most of these tools have been specially adapted for use by disabled people

def: to change your behavior in order to deal more successfully with a new situation
ex: It's amazing how soon you adapt
ex: The organisms were forced to adapt in order to survive
ex: adapt to something 
ex: We have had to adapt quickly to the new system
ex: A large organization can be slow to adapt to change
ex: adapt yourself to something 
ex: It took him a while to adapt himself to his new surroundings
ex: adapt something (for something) (from something) 

def: to change a book or play so that it can be made into a play, movie, TV show, etc.
ex: Three of her novels have been adapted for television

-----

word: add

def: to put something together with something else so as to increase the size, number, amount, etc.
ex: add something 
ex: Next add the flour
ex: The juice contains no added sugar
ex: The plan has the added (= extra) advantage of bringing employment to rural areas
ex: add something to something 
ex: A new wing was added to the building
ex: Shall I add your name to the list? 
ex: Chlorine is added to the water to kill bacteria

def: to put numbers or amounts together to get a total
ex: add A to B 
ex: Add 9 to the total
ex: add A and B together 
ex: If you add all these amounts together, you get a huge figure

def: to say something more; to make a further remark
ex: + speech 
ex: And don't be late, she added
ex: add something (to something) 
ex: I have nothing to add to my earlier statement
ex: add that 
ex: He added that they would return a week later
ex: add something (to something) 

def: to give a particular quality to an event, a situation, etc.
ex: This necklace will add a little class to your outfit

-----

word: addition

def: the process of adding two or more numbers together to find their total
ex: children learning addition and subtraction opposite subtract2 [countable] 
ex: addition (to something) 

def: a thing that is added to something else
ex: the latest addition to our line of cars 
ex: an addition to the family (= another child) 
ex: last-minute additions to the government's package of proposals3[uncountable] 
ex: addition (of something) 

def: the act of adding something to something else
ex: Pasta's basic ingredients are flour and water, sometimes with the addition of eggs or oil
ex: addition (to something) 

def: a new part that is added to a building
ex: architects who specialize in home additions 
ex: The addition should match the architecture of the house
ex: Bilingual children do better on IQ tests than children who speak only one language
ex: Learning another language not only improves children's job prospects in later life, but also boosts their self-esteem
ex: Teaching children a second language improves their job prospects in later life
ex: Another/One further/One additional reason for encouraging bilingual education is that it boosts children's self-esteem
ex: Studies suggest that bilingual children find it easier to learn additional languages
ex: His claim that children find bilingual education confusing is based on very little evidence
ex: Research has shown that first-language development is not impeded by exposure to a second language

def: more than was first mentioned or is usual
ex: additional resources/funds/security 
ex: The government provided an additional $25 million to expand the service

ex: Not long after that he resigned

ex: After winning the prize, she became famous overnight
ex: After an hour I went home (= when an hour had passed)
ex: It's ten after seven in the morning (= 7:10 a

def: used to show that something happens many times or continuously
ex: day after day of hot weather 
ex: I've told you time after time not to do that

def: behind someone when they have left; following someone
ex: Shut the door after you
ex: I'm always having to clean up after the kids (= clean the place after they have left it dirty or messy)
ex: He ran after her with the book
ex: She was left staring after him

def: next to and following someone or something in order or importance
ex: Your name comes after mine on the list
ex: He's the tallest, after Richard
ex: After you (= Please go first)
ex: I'll jump into the pool after she does

def: in contrast to something
ex: It was pleasantly cool in the house after the sticky heat outside

def: as a result of or because of something that has happened
ex: I'll never forgive him after what he said

def: despite something; although something has happened
ex: I can't believe she'd do that, not after all I've done for her

def: trying to find or catch someone or something
ex: The police are after him
ex: He's after a job at our place

def: about someone or something
ex: She asked after you (= how you were)

def: in the style of someone or something; following the example of someone or something
ex: a painting after Goya 
ex: We named the baby Lillian after her grandmother

def: happening or done later than the time or event mentioned
ex: after-hours drinking (= after closing time) 
ex: an after-school club 
ex: after-dinner mintsIdioms after all

-----

word: afternoon

def: the part of the day from 12 p.m. until about 6 p.m.
ex: this/yesterday/tomorrow afternoon 
ex: In the afternoon they went shopping
ex: She takes an art class two afternoons a week
ex: Are you ready for this afternoon's meeting? 
ex: The baby always has an afternoon nap
ex: Come over on Sunday afternoon
ex: Where were you on the afternoon ofMay 21? see also good afternoonCheck pronunciation: afternoon

-----

word: afterward

def: at a later time; after an event that has already been mentioned
ex: She was sorry afterward for what she said
ex: Let's go out now and eat afterward
ex: Shortly afterward he saw her again

-----

word: again

def: one more time; on another occasion
ex: Could you say it again, please? 
ex: When will I see you again? 
ex: This must never happen again
ex: Once again (= as had happened several times before), the train was late
ex: I've told you again and again (= many times) not to do that
ex: I'll have to write it all over again (= again from the beginning)

def: showing that someone or something is in the same place or state that they were in originally
ex: He was glad to be home again
ex: She spends two hours a day getting to work and back again
ex: You'll feel well again soon

def: used to show that a comment or fact is connected with what you have just said
ex: And again, we must think of the cost
ex: then/there again 

def: used to introduce a fact or an opinion that contrasts with what you have just said
ex: We might buy it, but then again, we might not

def: used when you ask someone to tell you something or repeat something that you think they have told you already
ex: What was the name again?Idioms against time

-----

word: against

def: opposing or disagreeing with someone or something
ex: the fight against terrorism 
ex: We're playing against the league champions next week
ex: We were rowing against the current
ex: That's against the law
ex: She was forced to marry against her will
ex: Are you for or against the death penalty? 
ex: She is against seeing (= does not want to see) him
ex: I'd advise you against doing that

def: not to the advantage or favor of someone or something
ex: The evidence is against him
ex: Her age is against her

def: close to, touching, or hitting someone or something
ex: Put the piano there, against the wall
ex: The rain beat against the windows

def: in order to prevent something from happening or to reduce the damage caused by something
ex: a vaccination against the measles 
ex: They took precautions against fire
ex: Are we insured against theft?5

def: with something in the background, as a contrast
ex: His red clothes stood out clearly against the snow
ex: The love story unfolds against a background of civil war

def: used when you are comparing two things
ex: You must weigh the benefits against the cost
ex: Check your receipts against the statement
ex: What's the exchange rate against the euro?Idioms as against something

ex: You're not leaving already, are you?3

def: used to emphasize that a situation or problem exists
ex: I'm already late
ex: There are far too many people already

ex: She's fluent in French and German
ex: rubella,also known asGerman measles

ex: His view is that photography is not art but merely the mechanical reproduction of images
ex: Smith takes the view that photography is both an art and a science

ex: I went to New York last year, and I also spent some time in Washington
ex: Im going home now
ex: Will your husband be attending as well?	When you want to add a second negative point in a negative sentence, use not
ex: She hasnt called and she hasnt written either
ex: You can have a burger, but you cant have a hot dog too

word: although

def: used for introducing a statement that makes the main statement in a sentence seem surprising
ex: Although the sun was shining, it wasn't very warm

ex: Politicians have promised to improve road safety

ex: I felt he was wrong, although I didn't say so at the time
ex: Although/Even though/Though everyone played well, we lost the game
ex: We lost the game, although/even though/though everyone played well

ex: Apart from their house in Connecticut, they also have a cottage in Nantucket
ex: It was a difficult time
ex: What other sports do you like besides football?You use except (for) when you mention the only thing that is not included in a statement:
ex: I like all sports except (for) football
ex: What other sports do you like apart from football? 
ex: I like all sports apart from football

ex: an army officer

an assault/a raid (on somebody)	employ/use guerrilla tactics	conduct/wage biological/guerrilla warfare	fight/crush/defeat the rebels/the insurgency	suffer/inflict a crushing defeat	achieve/win a decisive victory	halt/stop the American/German advance	order/force a retreatfighting	join/serve in the Army/Navy/Air Force/Marines/Coast Guard/reserves	be/go/remain/serve on active duty	do/complete/return from a tour of duty	be sent to the front (line)	attack/strike/engage/defeat/kill/destroy the enemy	witness/see/report/be engaged in heavy fighting	call for/be met with armed resistance	come under heavy/machine-gun/mortar fire	fire a machine gun/mortar shells/rockets (at somebody/something)	shoot a rifle/a pistol/bullets/missiles	launch/fire a(n) cruise/ballistic/anti-tank missile	use biological/chemical/nuclear weapons	inflict/suffer/sustain heavy losses/casualties	be hit/killed by enemy/friendly/artillery fire	become/be held as/be taken as a prisoner of warcivilians in war	harm/kill/target/protect innocent/unarmed civilians	cause/avoid/limit/minimize civilian casualties/collateral damage	impose/enforce/lift a curfew	engage in/be a victim of ethnic cleansing	be sent to a concentration/an internment camp	accept/house/resettle/turn away refugees fleeing from war	fear/threaten military/violent reprisals	commit/be accused of war crimes/crimes against humanity/genocidemaking peace	make/bring/win/achieve/maintain/promote peace	call for/negotiate/broker/declare a ceasefire/a temporary truce	sign a ceasefire agreement	call for/bring/put an end to hostilities	demand/negotiate/accept the surrender of somebody/something	establish/send (in) a peacekeeping force	negotiate/conclude/ratify/sign/accept/reject/break/violate a peace treaty3[countable] 

def: a large number of people or things, especially when they are organized in some way or involved in a particular activity
ex: an army of advisers/volunteers 
ex: An army of ants marched across the path

ex: There were papers lying around all over the floor

def: a strip of cloth used for covering or tying around a part of the body that has been hurt in order to protect or support it

word: bank

def: an organization that provides various financial services, for example keeping or lending money
ex: My salary is paid directly into my bank

ex: a bank loan see also commercial bank, investment bank, savings bank in gambling2

def: a supply of money or things that are used as money in some games, especially those in which gambling is involved

def: an amount of something that is collected; a place where something is stored ready for use
ex: a bank of knowledge 
ex: a blood/sperm bank see also data bank of river/canal4 

def: the side of a river, 
ex: He jumped in and swam to the opposite bank
ex: It's on the north bank of Lake Michigan
ex: a house on the banks of the Mississippi River (= on land near the river) slope5

def: a raised area of ground that slopes at the sides, often at the edge of something or dividing something
ex: There were low banks of earth between the rice fields
ex: The girls ran down the steep grassy bank

def: an artificial slope built at the side of a road, so that cars can drive fast around bends

def: a mass of cloud, snow, etc., especially one formed by the wind
ex: The sun disappeared behind a bank of clouds

def: a row or series of similar objects, especially machines
ex: a bank of lights/switches/computersIdioms laugh all the way to the bank (informal)

word: barely

def: in a way that is just possible but only with difficulty
ex: He could barely read and write
ex: The music was barely audible
ex: She was barely able to stand
ex: We barely had time to catch the train

def: in a way that almost does not happen or exist
ex: She barely acknowledged his presence
ex: There was barely any smell

def: just; certainly not more than (a particular amount, age, time, etc.)
ex: Barely 50% of the population voted
ex: He was barely 20 years old and already running his own company
ex: They arrived barely a minute later

def: only a very short time before
ex: I had barely started speaking when he interrupted me
ex: They have sold hardly any copies of the book
ex: We had scarcely any time between dinner and the show
ex: I barely recognized her
ex: His words were barely audible
ex: I can hardly believe it
ex: We had hardly/scarcely/barely sat down at the table, when the phone rang
ex: Hardly/Scarcely had we sat down at the table, when the phone rang
ex: I scarcely had time to ring the bell before the door opened
ex: No sooner had we sat down at the table than the phone rang
ex: She hardly (ever) sees her parents these days

ex: I picked up a few good bargains at the sale

word: barrier

def: an object like a fence that prevents people from moving forward from one place to another
ex: The crowd had to stand behind barriers
ex: Show your ticket at the barrier
ex: The car crashed into the safety barrier and burst into flames

def: a problem, rule, or situation that prevents someone from doing something, or that makes something impossible
ex: the removal of trade barriers 
ex: The act of learning knows no age barriers
ex: barrier to something 
ex: Lack of confidence is a psychological barrier to success
ex: Cost should not be a barrier to the use of legal services

def: something that exists between one thing or person and another and keeps them separate
ex: The Yangtze river is a natural barrier to the northeast
ex: the language barrier (= when people cannot communicate because they do not speak the same language) 
ex: barrier between A and B 
ex: There was no real barrier between reality and fantasy in his mind
ex: barrier against something 
ex: Ozone is the earth's barrier against ultraviolet radiation

def: a particular amount, level, or number which it is difficult to get past
ex: the first player whose earnings passed the $10 million barrier Thesaurusborderboundary frontier barrierThese are all words for a line that marks the edge of something and separates it from other areas or things
ex: a national park on the border between Montana and Wyomingboundary a line that marks the edges of an area of land and separates it from other areas:
ex: The fence marked the boundary between my property and hers
ex: After the war, the national boundaries were redrawn
ex: the boundary fence/wall between the propertiesfrontier the border between two countries or areas; a line that marks the beginning of an unexplored or dangerous area:
ex: the frontier between Guatemala and Mexico 
ex: The Ingalls family crossed the frontier in a covered wagon
ex: The mountains form a natural barrier between the ocean and the desert

ex: These figures formed the basis of their claim for compensation
ex: Her study laid the groundwork for my research
ex: This work provided us with a strong base upon which to build the company

def: the people, activity, etc. from which someone or something gets most of their support, income, power, etc.
ex: These policies have a broad base of support
ex: an economy with a solid manufacturing base 
ex: By broadening the tax base (= increasing the number of people who pay taxes) he could raise more revenue
ex: base pay/salary/wage 

def: the pay that you get before anything extra is added
ex: All we got was base paywe didn't reach profitability levels to earn a bonus

def: the first or main part of a substance to which other things are added
ex: a drink with a rum base 
ex: Put some moisturizer on as a base before applying your makeup

def: the main place where you live or stay or where a business operates from
ex: I spend a lot of time in Los Angeles, but Paris is still my base
ex: The town is an ideal base for touring the area
ex: You can use our apartment as a base in New York
ex: The company has its base in New York, and branch offices all over the world

ex: a military/naval base 
ex: an air base 
ex: After the attack, they returned to base

ex: the campaign for health care reform 
ex: an advertising campaignbattle a competition or argument between people or groups of people trying to win power or control:
ex: She finally won her legal battle
ex: the endless battle between man and naturestruggle a competition or argument between people or groups of people trying to win power or control:
ex: the struggle for independence 
ex: the struggle between good and evilbattle or struggle?These words are very similar and in many cases you can use either word
ex: the battle for the Republican nomination 
ex: her long struggle for recognitiondrive an organized effort by a group of people to achieve something:
ex: the drive for success 
ex: a drive to reduce energy consumption 
ex: a major fund drivecampaign or drive?A campaign is usually an attempt to get other people to do something, that takes place over a period of time; a drive may be a shorter or more local effort
ex: the war against povertyfight [sing
ex: Workers won their fight for better benefits and higher pay

word: before

def: earlier than someone or something
ex: before lunch 
ex: the day before yesterday 
ex: The year before last he won a gold medal, and the year before that he won a silver
ex: She's lived there since before the war
ex: He arrived before me
ex: She became a lawyer as her father had before her
ex: Leave your keys at the reception desk before departure
ex: Something should have been done before now
ex: We'll know before long (= soon)
ex: Turn left just before (= before you reach) the bank

def: used to say that someone or something is in a position in front of someone or something
ex: They knelt before the altar
ex: Before you is a list of the points we have to discuss

def: used to say that someone or something is ahead of someone or something in an order or arrangement
ex: Your name is before mine on the list
ex: He puts his work before everything (= regards it as more important than anything else)

def: used to say that something is facing someone in the future
ex: The task before us is a daunting one
ex: The whole summer lay before me

def: in the presence of someone who is listening, watching, etc.
ex: He was brought before the judge
ex: She said it before witnesses
ex: They had the advantage of playing before their home crowd

def: used to say how someone reacts when they have to face someone or something
ex: They retreated before the enemy

word: begin

def: to start doing something; to do the first part of something
ex: Shall I begin? 
ex: begin at/with something 
ex: Let's begin at page 9
ex: begin by doing something 
ex: She began by thanking us all for coming
ex: begin something 
ex: We began work on the project in May
ex: I began (= started reading) this novel last month and I still haven't finished it

ex: He always begins his lessons with a warm-up exercise

ex: He began his political career as a student (= when he was a student)

ex: I began to feel dizzy
ex: Finally the guests began to arrive
ex: She began to cry
ex: It was beginning to snow
ex: I was beginning to think you'd never come
ex: begin doing something 
ex: Everyone began talking at once
ex: When will you begin recruiting? Thesaurusstartbegin start off kick off commence openThese words are all used to talk about things happening from the beginning, or people doing the first part of something
ex: When does the class start?begin to start to happen or exist; to start in a particular way or from a particular point; to start speaking:
ex: When does the concert begin?start or begin?There is not much difference in meaning between these words
ex: The story begins on the island of Corfu
ex: The discussion started off mildly enough
ex: Tom will kick off with a few comments
ex: The festival kicks off on Monday with a free concert
ex: The negotiations are scheduled to commence at noon
ex: The story opens with a murder
ex: This study has the following aims:first, to investigate how international students in America use humor;second, to examine how jokes can help to establish social relationships; and, third, to explore the role that humor plays in helping overseas students adjust to life in the U
ex: Let us begin by identifying some of the popular joke genres in the U
ex: Next, let us turn to/Next, let us consider the question of gender differences in the use of humor
ex: Finally/Lastly, let us briefly examine the role of humor in defining a nation's culture

def: to start to happen or exist, especially from a particular time
ex: When does the concert begin? 
ex: Work on the new bridge is due to begin in September
ex: The evening began well
ex: begin as something 

def: to be something first, before becoming something else
ex: He began as an actor, before starting to direct films
ex: What began as a minor scuffle turned into a full-scale riot

def: to have something as the first part or the point where something starts
ex: Where does Europe end and Asia begin? 
ex: begin with something 
ex: Use an before words beginning with a vowel
ex: I'm thinking of a country in Asia
ex: Each chapter begins with a quotation
ex: begin at 
ex: The path begins at the edge of the village
ex: + speech 

def: to start speaking
ex: Ladies and gentlemen, he began, welcome to the Town Hall

def: to start or make something start for the first time
ex: The school began in 1920, with only ten students
ex: begin something 
ex: He began a new magazine on postwar architecture
ex: not begin to do something 

def: to make no attempt to do something or have no chance of doing something
ex: Ican't begin to thank you enough
ex: He couldn't even begin to understand my problem

def: to feel certain that something is true or that someone is telling you the truth

ex: Three sailors are missing, believed drowned

ex: What do you think about Matt's new girlfriend?believe to have an idea that something is true or possible, although you are not completely certain; to have a particular opinion about someone or something:
ex: Police believe (that) the man may be armed
ex: Police believe 
ex: I thinkWhen you are expressing an opinion, believe is stronger than think and is used especially for matters of principle;think is used more for practical matters or matters of personal taste
ex: We all felt (that) we had been cheated
ex: I was under the impression that the work had already been completed
ex: believe (that) 

def: to have the opinion that something is right or true
ex: The candidate believes (that) education is the most important issue facing the government
ex: She believes that killing animals for food or fur is completely immoral

word: between

ex: It's cheaper between 6 p
ex: Don't eat between meals
ex: Children must attend school between the ages of 5 and 16
ex: Many changes took place between the two world wars

def: at some point along a scale from one amount, weight, distance, etc. to another
ex: It weighed between nine and ten pounds
ex: The temperature remained between 75F and 80F all week

def: separating one place from another
ex: the border between Oregon and Washington5 

def: from one place to another
ex: We fly between Chicago and Dallas twice daily

def: used to show a connection or relationship
ex: a difference/distinction/contrast between two things 
ex: a link between unemployment and crime 
ex: There's a lot of bad feelings between them
ex: I had to choose between the two jobs

def: shared by two or more people or things
ex: We ate a pizza between us
ex: This is just between you and me/between ourselves (= it is a secret)

def: by putting together the efforts or actions of two or more people or groups
ex: We should be able to manage it between us
ex: China and India between them account for more than a third of the world's population
ex: between doing something 

def: used to show that several activities are involved
ex: Between working full-time and taking care of the kids, he didn't have much time for hobbies

ex: I invited everyone, but only two people came
ex: By the end of the day, we were tired but happy
ex: While the movie is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing work of art
ex: It can be argued that the movie is too long
ex: The movie is undoubtedly too long
ex: Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling
ex: Critics are wrong to argue that the movie's plot is too complicated
ex: It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent movie
ex: It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre

def: used when you are saying sorry about something
ex: I'm sorry, but I can't stay any longer

def: used to introduce a statement that shows that you are surprised or annoyed, or that you disagree
ex: But that's not possible! 
ex: Here's the money I owe you

def: except
ex: I had no choice but to sign the contract

def: used before repeating a word in order to emphasize it
ex: Nothing, but nothing would make him change his mind

def: used to emphasize that something is always true
ex: She never passed her old home but she thought of the happy years she had spent there (= she always thought of them)

word: by

def: near someone or something; at the side of someone or something; beside someone or something
ex: a house by the river

ex: Come and sit by me

def: used, usually after a passive verb, to show who or what does, creates, or causes something
ex: He was knocked down by a bus
ex: a play by Ibsen 
ex: Who's that book by? 
ex: I was frightened by the noise

def: used for showing how or in what way something is done
ex: The house is heated by gas
ex: May I pay by check? 
ex: I will contact you by mail
ex: to travel by boat/bus/car/plane 
ex: to travel by air/land/sea 
ex: Switch it on by pressing this button

ex: They met by chance
ex: I did it by mistake
ex: The coroner's verdict was death by strangulation

def: not later than the time mentioned; before
ex: Can you finish the work by five o'clock? 
ex: I'll have it done by tomorrow
ex: By this time next week we'll be in New York

ex: By the time (that) this letter reaches you, I will have left the country

ex: He walked by me without speaking

def: during something; in a particular situation
ex: to travel by day/night 
ex: We had to work by candlelight

def: used to show the degree or amount of something
ex: The bullet missed him by two inches
ex: House prices went up by 10%
ex: It would be better by far (= much better) to9

def: from what something shows or says; according to something
ex: By my watch it is two o'clock
ex: I could tell by the look on her face that something terrible had happened
ex: By law, you are a child until you are 18

def: used to show the part of someone or something that someone touches, holds, etc.
ex: I took him by the hand
ex: She seized her by the arm
ex: Pick it up by the handle!11 

def: used with 
ex: We rented the car by the day
ex: They're paid by the hour
ex: We only sell it by the yard

def: used to state the rate at which something happens
ex: They're improving day by day
ex: We'll do it bit by bit
ex: It was getting worse by the minute (= very fast)
ex: The children came in two by two (= in groups of two)

def: used for giving more information about where someone comes from, what someone does, etc.
ex: He's German by birth
ex: They're both doctors by profession

def: used when swearing to mean in the name of
ex: I swear by Almighty God15

def: used to show the measurements of something
ex: The room measures fifteen feet by twenty feet

def: used when multiplying or dividing
ex: 6 multiplied by 2 equals 12
ex: 6 divided by 2 equals 3

ex: Would you call it blue or green? Thesaurusregardcall find consider see viewThese words all mean to think about someone or something in a particular way
ex: He seemed to regard the whole thing as a joke
ex: I wouldn't call German an easy language
ex: You may find his story hard to believe
ex: Whom do you consider (to be) responsible for the accident?regard or consider?These two words have the same meaning, but they are used in different patterns and structures
ex: He considers himself an expert
ex: They are considered a high-risk group
ex: Try to see things from her point of view
ex: How do you view your position within the company? View has the same meaning as regard and consider but is slightly less frequent and slightly less formal

ex: the campaign for health care reform 
ex: an advertising campaignbattle a competition or argument between people or groups of people trying to win power or control:
ex: She finally won her legal battle
ex: the endless battle between man and naturestruggle a competition or argument between people or groups of people trying to win power or control:
ex: the struggle for independence 
ex: the struggle between good and evilbattle or struggle?These words are very similar and in many cases you can use either word
ex: the battle for the Republican nomination 
ex: her long struggle for recognitiondrive an organized effort by a group of people to achieve something:
ex: the drive for success 
ex: a drive to reduce energy consumption 
ex: a major fund drivecampaign or drive?A campaign is usually an attempt to get other people to do something, that takes place over a period of time; a drive may be a shorter or more local effort
ex: the war against povertyfight [sing
ex: Workers won their fight for better benefits and higher pay

word: can

def: used to say that it is possible for someone or something to do something, or for something to happen
ex: I can run fast
ex: Can you call back tomorrow? 
ex: He couldn't answer the question
ex: The stadium can be emptied in four minutes
ex: I can't promise anything, but I'll do what I can
ex: Please let us know if you cannot attend the meeting

def: used to say that someone knows how to do something
ex: She can speak Spanish
ex: Can he cook? 
ex: She could read before she started kindergarten

def: used with the verbs feel, hear, see, smell, taste
ex: She could feel the cool air on her face
ex: I can hear music

def: used to show that someone is allowed to do something
ex: You can take the car if you want
ex: We can't wear jeans at work

def: used to ask permission to do something
ex: Can I read your newspaper? 
ex: Can I take you home?6(informal) 

def: used to ask someone to help you
ex: Can you help me with this box? 
ex: Can you feed the cat, please?7

def: used in the negative for saying that you are sure something is not true
ex: That can't be Maryshe's in New York
ex: He can't have slept through all that noise

def: used to express doubt or surprise
ex: What can they be doing? 
ex: Can he be serious? 
ex: Where could she have put it?9 

def: used to say what someone or something is often like
ex: He can be very tactless sometimes
ex: It can be really cold here in the winter

def: used to make suggestions
ex: We can eat in a restaurant if you like
ex: I can take the car if necessary

def: used to say that someone must do something, usually when you are angry
ex: You can be quiet or get out! Grammarmodal verbsThe modal verbs are can, could, may, might, must, ought to, shall, should, will, and would
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results

ex: Don't worryit's a sure thing

ex: That method is guaranteed to take much longer

-----

word: certainly

def: without doubt
ex: Without treatment, she will almost certainly die
ex: Certainly, the early years are crucial to a child's development
ex: I'm certainly never going there again
ex: She was certainly attractive but you couldn't call her beautiful
ex: Surely this cant be right?Surely in negative sentences shows that something surprises you and you do not want to believe it:
ex: Surely youre not thinking of going, are you?	Certainly is more formal and usually means without doubt or definitely, and is used to show that you strongly believe something or to emphasize that something is really true:
ex: Ill certainly remember this trip!In informal English, this would be:
ex: Ill sure remember this trip!Compare:
ex: She's certainly too busy to see you this week (= there is no doubt about it)and
ex: Surely she's too busy to see you this week (= that is my opinion
ex: This will surely end in disaster
ex: While the movie is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing work of art
ex: It can be argued that the movie is too long
ex: The movie is undoubtedly too long
ex: Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling
ex: Critics are wrong to argue that the movie's plot is too complicated
ex: It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent movie
ex: It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre

def: of course
ex: May I see your passport, Mr
ex: Do you think all this money will change your life? Certainly not

ex: Whom do you consider (to be) responsible for the accident?regard or consider?These two words have the same meaning, but they are used in different patterns and structures

ex: They are considered a high-risk group
ex: Try to see things from her point of view
ex: How do you view your position within the company? View has the same meaning as regard and consider but is slightly less frequent and slightly less formal

ex: Am I correct in saying that you know a lot about wine? opposite incorrect Thesaurustrueright correctThese words all describe something that cannot be doubted as fact and includes no mistakes
ex: Are the following statements true or false? 
ex: Is it true that she's leaving?right that is true and cannot be doubted as a fact:
ex: I got about half the answers right
ex: Only one of the answers is correct

word: could

def: used as the past tense of can
ex: She said that she couldn't come
ex: I couldn't hear what they were saying
ex: Sorry, I couldn't get any more
ex: Can you play the piano?It is also used with verbs of seeing, noticing, etc:
ex: I can hear someone calling, and with passive infinitives:
ex: The DVD can be found online
ex: Can you/Are you able to come on Saturday?You use be able to to form the future and perfect tenses and the infinitive:
ex: Youll be able to get a taxi outside the station
ex: I havent been able to get much work done today
ex: Shed love to be able to play the piano
ex: Our daughter could walk when she was nine months old
ex: I was able to/managed to find some useful books in the library
ex: We werent able to/didnt manage to/couldnt get there in time
ex: I could see there was something wrong
ex: I could have won the game but decided to let him win instead

def: used to ask if you can do something
ex: Could I use your phone, please? 
ex: Could we stop by next week?3

def: used to politely ask someone to do something for you
ex: Could you babysit for us on Friday?4

def: used to show that something is or might be possible
ex: I could do it now, if you like
ex: Don't worrythey could have just forgotten to call
ex: You couldn't have left it on the bus, could you? 
ex: Have some more cake

def: used to suggest something
ex: We could write a letter to the director
ex: You could always try his home number

def: used to show that you are annoyed that someone did not do something
ex: They could have let me know they were going to be late!7(informal) 

def: used to emphasize how strongly you want to express your feelings
ex: I'm so fed up I could scream! Grammarmodal verbsThe modal verbs are can, could, may, might, must, ought to, shall, should, will, and would
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results

ex: Climate change can/may be defined as the long-term fluctuations in temperature, precipitation, wind, and other aspects of the earth's climate
ex: A generally accepted definition of global warming is the gradual increase in the overall temperature of the earth's atmosphere due to the greenhouse effect
ex: The greenhouse effect is defined by the author as the process by which heat from the sun is trapped in the earth's atmosphere, causing the temperature of the earth to rise
ex: The author uses the term climate changeto refer to any significant change in measures of climate lasting for an extended period
ex: The term carbon footprintrefers to the amount of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of the activities of an individual or organization
ex: Scientists suggest that increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere will result in an increase in global temperatures, and the term global warmingis used to describe this phenomenon

def: what an idea, etc. means
ex: What's your definition of happiness? 
ex: There is no agreed definition of what a comprehensive school should be

def: the quality of being clear and easy to see
ex: Digital TV screens have excellent definition

def: an act or the process of finding someone or something, or learning about something that was not known about before
ex: discovery (of something) 
ex: the discovery of antibiotics in the 20th century 
ex: The discovery of a child's body in the river has shocked the community
ex: the discovery of new talent in the art world 
ex: Researchers in this field have made some important new discoveries
ex: He saw life as a voyage of discovery
ex: discovery (that) 
ex: She was shocked by the discovery that he had been unfaithful
ex: In 1974 Hawking made the discovery (= he discovered) that black holes give off radiation

def: a thing, fact, or person that is found or learned about for the first time
ex: The drug is not a new discoveryit's been known about for years

ex: enable something 
ex: a new subway line to enable easier access to the stadium Language Bankprocessdescribing a process	
ex: This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making
ex: First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips
ex: Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine
ex: Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed
ex: Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities
ex: The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt
ex: As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away
ex: At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper
ex: The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls

word: even

ex: She's even more intelligent than her sister

ex: It's my best ever score

def: an act of not doing something, especially something that you are expected to do
ex: the failure of the United Nations to maintain food supplies 
ex: Failure to comply with the regulations will result in prosecution
ex: His confession followed repeated failures to appear in court

def: the state of not working correctly or as expected; an occasion when this happens
ex: patients suffering from heart/kidney, etc
ex: Production has been halted by mechanical failure
ex: A power failure plunged everything into darkness
ex: The cause of the crash was given as engine failure
ex: business/bank failure 

def: a situation in which a business or bank has to close because it is not successful
ex: an alarming increase in bank failures of crops6 [uncountable, countable] 
ex: crop failure 

def: a situation in which crops do not grow correctly and do not produce food
ex: Bad weather has resulted in crop failure

-----

word: faint

def: that cannot be clearly seen, heard, or smelled
ex: a faint glow/glimmer/light 
ex: a faint smell of perfume 
ex: We saw the faint outline of the mountain through the mist
ex: We could hear their voices growing fainter as they walked down the road
ex: His breathing became faint

def: very small; possible but unlikely
ex: There is still a faint hope that she may be cured
ex: They don't have the faintest chance of winning

def: not enthusiastic
ex: a faint show of resistance 
ex: a faint smile4[not before noun] 

def: feeling weak and tired and likely to become unconscious
ex: She suddenly felt faint
ex: The walkers were faint from hunger

-----

word: fair

def: acceptable and appropriate in a particular situation
ex: a fair deal/price/question 
ex: The punishment was very fair
ex: In the end, a draw was a fair result
ex: I'm giving you fair warning, I'm not always this generous
ex: fair to somebody (to do something) 
ex: Was it really fair to him to ask him to do all the work? 
ex: fair to do something 
ex: It's only fair to add that they were not told about the problem until the last minute
ex: I think it is fair to say that they are pleased with the latest offer
ex: fair that 
ex: It seems only fair that they give us something in return
ex: To be fair, she behaved better than we expected

def: treating everyone equally and according to the rules or law
ex: She has always been scrupulously fair
ex: demands for a fairer distribution of wealth 
ex: fair (to somebody) 
ex: We have to be fair to both players
ex: to receive a fair trial 
ex: free and fair elections 
ex: It's not fair!He always gets more than me
ex: The new tax is fairer than the old system
ex: They are fair and decent employers
ex: his vision of a fairer, kinder society opposite unfair fairly large3 [only before noun] 

def: fairly large in number, size, or amount
ex: A fair number of people came along
ex: a fair-sized town 
ex: We've still got a fair amount (= some more things) to do
ex: My birthday's still a fair way off (= it's still a long time until my birthday)

def: fairly good
ex: There's a fair chance that we might win this time
ex: It's a fair bet that they won't turn up
ex: I have a fair idea of what happened
ex: His knowledge of French is only fair

def: pale in color
ex: a fair complexion 
ex: She has long, fair hair
ex: All her children are fair (= they all have pale hair or skin)

def: bright and not raining
ex: a fair and breezy day7(literary) (of winds) 

def: not too strong and blowing in the right direction
ex: They set sail with the first fair wind

def: beautiful
ex: a fair maidenIdioms all's fair in love and war (saying)

word: fairly

def: to some extent but not very
ex: a fairly easy book 
ex: a fairly typical reaction 
ex: I know him fairly well, but I wouldn't say we were really close friends
ex: I go jogging fairly regularly
ex: We'll have to leave fairly soon (= before very long)
ex: I'm fairly certain I can do the job
ex: I think you'll find it fairly difficult (= you do not want to say that it is very difficult)

def: in a fair and reasonable way; honestly
ex: He has always treated me very fairly
ex: Her attitude could fairly be described as hostile

def: used to emphasize something that you are saying
ex: The time fairly raced by

def: not having a sexual relationship with anyone else

ex: September had come and the leaves were starting to fall

ex: Several of the books had fallen onto the floor
ex: One of the kids fell into the river
ex: The handle had fallen off the drawer
ex: He fell 20 feet onto the rocks below
ex: The rain was falling steadily

def: to suddenly stop standing
ex: She slipped on the ice and fell
ex: + adv
ex: Ifell down and cut my knee
ex: The house looked like it was about to fall down
ex: + adv

def: to hang down
ex: Her hair fell over her shoulders in a mass of curls
ex: fall (away/off) 

def: to slope downward
ex: The land falls away sharply toward the river

def: to decrease in amount, number, or strength
ex: Their profits have fallen by 30 percent
ex: Prices continued to fall on the stock market today
ex: The temperature fell sharply during the night
ex: falling birth rates 
ex: Her voice fell to a whisper
ex: + noun 
ex: The company's share price fell 30 cents

def: to be defeated or captured
ex: The coup failed but the government fell shortly afterward
ex: fall to somebody 
ex: Troy finally fell to the Greeks

def: to die in battle; to be shot
ex: a memorial to those who fell in the two world wars become8 [intransitive]

ex: The room had fallen silent
ex: She fell ill soon after and did not recover
ex: fall into something 
ex: I had fallen into conversation with a man on the train
ex: The house had fallen into disrepair
ex: + noun 
ex: She knew she must not fall prey to his charm

def: to come quickly and suddenly
ex: A sudden silence fell
ex: Darkness falls quickly in the tropics
ex: + adv

def: to happen or take place
ex: My birthday falls on a Monday this year
ex: + adv

def: to move in a particular direction or come in a particular position
ex: Which syllable does the stress fall on?

ex: A shadow fell across her face
ex: + adv

def: to belong to a particular class, group, or area of responsibility
ex: Out of more than 400 staff, there are just seven that fall into this category
ex: This case falls outside my jurisdiction
ex: This falls under the heading of scientific research

word: far

def: a long distance away
ex: We didn't go far
ex: Have you come far? 
ex: It's not far to the beach
ex: There's not far to go now
ex: far (from, away, below, etc
ex: The restaurant is not far from here
ex: countries as far apart as Japan and Brazil 
ex: He looked down at the traffic far below
ex: Far away in the distance, a train whistled
ex: The farther north they went, the colder it became
ex: a concert of music from near and far In positive sentences it is more usual to use a long way:
ex: We went a long way
ex: The restaurant is a long way from here

def: used when you are asking or talking about the distance between two places, or the distance that has been traveled or is to be traveled
ex: How far is it to your house from here? 
ex: How far is Boston from New York? 
ex: How much farther is it? 
ex: We'll go by train as far asBoston, and then take a bus
ex: We didn't go as far as the others
ex: I'm not sure I can walk so far

def: a long time from the present; for a large part of a particular period of time
ex: far back 
ex: The band made their first record as far back as 1990
ex: To answer that question we need to go farther back in time
ex: far ahead 
ex: Let's try to plan farther ahead
ex: far into something 
ex: We worked far into the night

def: very much; to a great degree
ex: That's a far better idea
ex: There are far more opportunities for young people than there used to be
ex: It had been a success far beyond their expectations
ex: He's fallen far behind in his work
ex: She always gives us far too much homework

def: used when you are asking or talking about the degree to which something is true or possible
ex: How far can we trust him? 
ex: His parents supported him as far as they could
ex: Plan your route in advance, using main roads as far as possible

def: used to talk about how much progress has been made in doing or achieving something
ex: How far have you gotten with that report? 
ex: Half an hour later David was no farther in his quest
ex: I read as far as the third chapter
ex: We've gotten as far as collecting our data but we haven't analyzed it yet

word: fault

def: the responsibility for something wrong that has happened or been done
ex: Why should I say sorry when it's not my fault? 
ex: It's nobody's fault

ex: It was his fault that we were late
ex: fault (for doing something) 
ex: It's your own fault for being careless
ex: Many people live in poverty through no fault of their own
ex: I think the owners are at fault (= responsible) for not warning us
ex: She believes that the product's poor image is partly the fault of the press

def: a bad or weak aspect of someone's character
ex: He's proud of his children and blind to their faults
ex: I love her for all her faults (= in spite of them)
ex: I think my worst fault is impatience

def: something that is wrong or not perfect with something; something that is wrong with a machine or system that stops it from working correctly
ex: The book's virtues far outweigh its faults
ex: The system,for all its faults, is the best available at the present time
ex: a major fault in the design 
ex: a structural fault 
ex: an electrical fault in tennis4[countable] 

def: a mistake made when 
ex: He has served a number of double faults in this set

ex: the San Andreas fault 
ex: a fault lineIdioms find fault (with somebody/something)

ex: The suggestion to close the road has found favor with (= been supported by) local people
ex: The program has lost favor with viewers recently

ex: As a coach, she showed no favor to any of the girls on the softball team

def: agreement to have sex with someone

word: final

def: being or happening at the end of a series of events, actions, statements, etc.
ex: his final act as senator 
ex: The referee blew the final whistle
ex: The project is in its final stages
ex: They find each other in the final chapter of the book
ex: I'd like to return to the final point you made
ex: This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making
ex: First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips
ex: Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine
ex: Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed
ex: Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities
ex: The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt
ex: As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away
ex: At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper
ex: The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls

def: being the result of a particular process
ex: the final product 
ex: No one could have predicted the final outcome

def: that cannot be argued with or changed
ex: The judge's decision is final
ex: Who has the final say around here? 
ex: I'll give you $500 for it, and that's my final offer! 
ex: I'm not coming,and that's final! (= I will not change my mind)Idioms in the final/last analysis

ex: He seemed to regard the whole thing as a joke
ex: I wouldn't call German an easy language
ex: You may find his story hard to believe
ex: Whom do you consider (to be) responsible for the accident?regard or consider?These two words have the same meaning, but they are used in different patterns and structures
ex: He considers himself an expert
ex: They are considered a high-risk group
ex: Try to see things from her point of view
ex: How do you view your position within the company? View has the same meaning as regard and consider but is slightly less frequent and slightly less formal
ex: find something 

def: to have something available so that you can use it
ex: I keep meaning to write, but never seem to find (the) time
ex: How are we going to find $10,000 for a car? in unexpected situations7 [transitive] 

def: to discover someone or something/yourself doing something or in a particular situation, especially when this is unexpected
ex: find somebody/something/yourself + adv
ex: She woke up and found herself in a hospital bed
ex: find somebody/something/yourself + adj
ex: We came home and found him asleep on the sofa
ex: find somebody/something/yourself doing something 
ex: I suddenly found myself running down the street
ex: find (that) 
ex: I was disappointed to find that they had already left
ex: find something (of things) 

def: to arrive at something naturally; to reach something
ex: Most of the money finds its way to the people who need it
ex: The criticism found its mark (= had the intended effect)
ex: find something + adv

def: used to say that something exists, grows, etc. somewhere
ex: These cacti are found only in the Southwest
ex: You'll find this style of architecture all over New Orleans

def: to make a particular decision in a court case
ex: find somebody + adj
ex: The jury found him guilty
ex: How do you find the accused? 
ex: find in somebody's favor 
ex: The court found in her favor

ex: a trouble-free life not attached/trapped9
ex: free (of something) 

def: not attached to something or trapped by something
ex: Pull gently on the free end of the rope
ex: They had to be cut free from their car after the accident
ex: She finally managed to pull herself free

def: not being used
ex: He held out his free hand and I took it
ex: Is this seat free? not busy11
ex: free (for something) (of a person or time) 

def: without particular plans or arrangements; not busy
ex: If Sarah is free for lunch I'll take her out
ex: Keep Friday night free for my party
ex: What do you like to do in your free time (= when you are not working)? ready to give12
ex: free with something (often disapproving) 

def: ready to give something, especially when it is not wanted
ex: He's too free with his opinions

def: the right to do or say what you want without anyone stopping you
ex: freedom of speech/thought/expression/worship

ex: complete freedom to do whatever you want

ex: He finally won his freedom after twenty years in jail
ex: freedom from something 

def: the state of not being affected by the thing mentioned
ex: freedom from fear/pain/hunger, etc

word: freely

def: without anyone trying to prevent or control something
ex: the country's first freely elected president 
ex: Workers were allowed to travel freely between the two countries
ex: the right to worship freely

ex: When the gate is raised, the water can flow freely
ex: Traffic is now moving more freely following an earlier accident
ex: The book is now freely available in the stores (= it is not difficult to get a copy)
ex: Once in the open street they could breathe more freely
ex: The wine flowed freely (= there was a lot of it to drink)

def: without trying to avoid the truth even though it might be unpleasant or embarrassing
ex: I freely admit that I made a mistake
ex: Both players freely acknowledge that money was a major incentive

def: in an honest way without worrying about what people will say or do
ex: For the first time he was able to speak freely without the fear of reprisals against his family

def: in a willing and generous way
ex: Millions of people gave freely in response to the appeal for the victims of the earthquake
ex: She has always given freely of her time

def: a piece of writing that is translated

word: gap

ex: a gap in the conversation

ex: There's a big age gap between them (= a big difference in their ages)

def: a difference that separates people, or their opinions, situation, etc.
ex: the gap between rich and poor 
ex: the gap between theory and practice see also credibility, generation gap4

def: a space where something is missing
ex: His death left an enormous gap in my life
ex: There were several gaps in my education
ex: We think we've identified a gap in the market (= a business opportunity to make or sell something that is not yet available)

word: general

def: affecting all or most people, places, or things
ex: The general opinion is that the conference was a success
ex: the general belief/consensus 
ex: books of general interest (= of interest to most people) usual2[usually before noun] 

def: normal; usual
ex: There is one exception to this general principle
ex: As a general rule (= usually) he did what he could to be helpful
ex: This opinion is common among the general population (= ordinary people)

def: including the most important aspects of something; not exact or detailed
ex: I checked the weather forecast to get a general idea of what activities to plan
ex: I know how it works in general terms
ex: They gave a general description of the man
ex: the general direction/area 

def: approximately, but not exactly, the direction/area mentioned
ex: They fired in the general direction of the enemy

def: not limited to a particular subject, use, or activity
ex: a general hospital 
ex: general education 
ex: We will at this stage keep the discussion fairly general

def: not limited to one part or aspect of a person or thing
ex: a general anesthetic 
ex: The building was in a general state of disrepair

def: highest in rank; chief
ex: the general manager 
ex: the Inspector General see also attorney general, Governor General, Secretary General, Solicitor General, Surgeon GeneralIdioms in general

word: generally

def: by or to most people
ex: The plan was generally welcomed
ex: It is now generally accepted that 
ex: The new drug will be generally available in January
ex: He was a generally unpopular choice for captain

def: in most cases
ex: I generally get up at six
ex: The male is generally larger with a shorter beak

def: without discussing the details of something
ex: Let's talk just about investment generally
ex: Women generally earn less than men
ex: Generally speaking, jobs traditionally done by women are paid at a lower rate than those traditionally done by men
ex: In general/By and large, women do not earn as much as men
ex: Certain jobs, like nursing and cleaning, are still mainly carried out by women
ex: Senior management posts are held predominantly by men
ex: Most senior management posts tend to be held by men
ex: Women are, for the most part, still paid less than men
ex: Economic and social factors are, to a large extent, responsible for women being concentrated in low-paid jobs

def: definitely true and based on information that can be proved
ex: Is there any hard evidence either way? 
ex: The newspaper story is based on hard facts

def: very cold and severe
ex: It had been a hard winter
ex: There was a hard frost that night

def: strongly alcoholic
ex: hard liquor (informal) 
ex: a drop of the hard stuff (= a strong alcoholic drink) compare soft drink water11

def: containing 
ex: a hard water area 
ex: Our water is very hard

def: used to describe a letter 

-----

word: hardly

def: almost no; almost not; almost none
ex: There's hardly any coffee left
ex: Hardly anyone has bothered to reply
ex: She hardly ever calls me (= almost never)
ex: We hardly know each other
ex: Hardly a day goes by when I don't think about her (= I think of her almost every day)
ex: At the time, I hardly spoke any French
ex: There was hardly a cloud in the sky

def: used especially after can or could and before the main verb, to emphasize that it is difficult to do something
ex: I can hardly keep my eyes open (= I'm almost falling asleep)
ex: Icould hardly believe it when I read the letter

def: used to say that something has just begun, happened, etc.
ex: We can't stop for coffee now, we've hardly started
ex: We had hardly sat down to supper when the phone rang
ex: Hardly had she spoken than she regretted it bitterly

def: used to suggest that something is unlikely or unreasonable or that someone is silly for saying or doing something
ex: He is hardly likely to admit he was wrong
ex: It's hardly surprising she was fired; she never did any work
ex: It's hardly the time to discuss it now
ex: You can hardly expect her to do it for free
ex: Couldn't you have just said no? Well, hardly (= of course not), she's my wife's sister
ex: He's 24hardly a baby
ex: I have to work hard today
ex: She has thought very hard about her future plans
ex: It was raining hard outside
ex: I hardly ever go to concerts
ex: I can hardly wait for my birthday
ex: They have sold hardly any copies of the book
ex: We had scarcely any time between dinner and the show
ex: I barely recognized her
ex: His words were barely audible
ex: I can hardly believe it
ex: We had hardly/scarcely/barely sat down at the table, when the phone rang
ex: Hardly/Scarcely had we sat down at the table, when the phone rang
ex: I scarcely had time to ring the bell before the door opened
ex: No sooner had we sat down at the table than the phone rang
ex: She hardly (ever) sees her parents these days

-----

word: harm

def: damage or injury that is caused by a person or an event
ex: He would never frighten anyone or cause them any harm
ex: He may look fierce, but he means no harm
ex: The court case will do serious harm to my business
ex: The accident could have been much worse; luckily no harm was done
ex: Don't worry, we'll see that the children come to no harm
ex: I can't say I like Mark very much, but I don't wish him any harm
ex: Hard work never did anyone any harm
ex: Look, we're just going out for a few drinks,where's the harm in that? 
ex: The treatment they gave him did him more harm than good

-----

word: harmful

def: causing damage or injury to someone or something, especially to a person's health or to the environment
ex: the harmful effects of alcohol 
ex: the sun's harmful ultraviolet rays 
ex: Many household products are potentially harmful
ex: harmful to somebody/something 
ex: Fruit juices can be harmful to children's teeth

-----

word: harmless

def: unable or unlikely to cause damage or harm
ex: The bacteria is harmless to humans

def: unlikely to upset or offend anyone
ex: It's just a little harmless fun

ex: Do the children have to wear uniforms?In negative sentences, both must not and dont have to are used, but with different meanings
ex: Employees must not smoke in the building
ex: You mustnt leave the gate open
ex: You dont have to pay for the tickets in advance
ex: She doesnt have to work on weekends
ex: He has (got) to be the worst actor on TV!If you are talking about the past, use must have:

word: have to

def: used to show that you must do something
ex: Sorry, I've got to go
ex: Did she have to pay a fine? 
ex: You don't have to knockjust walk in
ex: I've got to leave by seven
ex: First, you have to think logically about your fears
ex: I have to admit, the idea of marriage scares me
ex: Do you have to go?2(also have got to) 

def: used to give advice or recommend something
ex: You simply have to get a new job
ex: You've got to try this recipeit's delicious

def: used to say that something must be true or must happen
ex: There has to be a reason for his strange behavior
ex: This war has got to end soon

def: used to suggest that an annoying event happens in order to annoy you, or that someone does something in order to annoy you
ex: Of course, it had to start raining as soon as we got to the beach
ex: Do you have to hum so loudly? (= it is annoying) Grammarmodal verbsThe modal verbs are can, could, may, might, must, ought to, shall, should, will, and would
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results
ex: You have to be home by 11 oclock
ex: I have to wash the car tomorrow
ex: I have to collect the children from school at 3 oclock
ex: All nurses must wear uniform
ex: Changes must be recorded in the log book
ex: I had to wait half an hour for a bus
ex: Well have to borrow the money we need
ex: I have to go to the dentist tomorrow
ex: Do the children have to wear uniforms?In negative sentences, both must not and dont have to are used, but with different meanings
ex: Employees must not smoke in the building
ex: You mustnt leave the gate open
ex: You dont have to pay for the tickets in advance
ex: She doesnt have to work on weekends
ex: He has (got) to be the worst actor on TV!If you are talking about the past, use must have:
ex: Your trip must have been fun!Check pronunciation: have to

ex: She is hoping to win the gold medal
ex: We hope to arrive around two
ex: What had he hoped to achieve? Hope can be used in the passive in the form it is hoped that
ex: The improvement that had been hoped for never came
