word: if

def: used to say that one thing can, will, or might happen or be true, depending on another thing happening or being true
ex: If you see him, give him this note
ex: I'll only stay if you offer me more money
ex: If necessary I can come at once
ex: You can stay for the weekend if you like
ex: If anyone calls, tell them I'm not at home
ex: If he improved his IT skills, he'd (= he would) easily get a job
ex: You would know what was going on if you'd (= you had) listened
ex: They would have been here by now if they'd caught the early train
ex: If I were in charge, I'd do things differently
ex: Even if (= although) you did see someone, you can't be sure it was him

def: when; whenever; every time
ex: If metal gets hot it expands
ex: She glares at me if I go near her desk

def: used with 
ex: If you will sit down for a few moments, I'll tell the manager you're here
ex: If you would care to leave your name, we'll contact you as soon as possible

def: used after 
ex: Do you know if he's married? 
ex: I wonder if I should wear a coat or not
ex: He couldn't tell if she was laughing or crying
ex: Listen to the tune and see if you can remember the words

def: used after verbs or adjectives expressing feelings
ex: I am sorry if I disturbed you
ex: I'd be grateful if you would keep it a secret
ex: Do you mind if I turn the TV off?6

def: used to admit that something is possible, but to say that it is not very important
ex: If she has any weakness, it is her Italian
ex: So what if he was late

def: used before an adjective to introduce a contrast
ex: He's a good driver, if a little overconfident
ex: We'll only do it onceif at all

def: used to ask someone to listen to your opinion
ex: If you ask me, she's too scared to do it
ex: If you think about it, those children must be at school by now
ex: If you remember, Mary was always fond of animals

def: used before 
ex: If I may make a suggestion, perhaps we could begin a little earlier next week
ex: She asked if/whether I wanted a drink

word: illustrate

def: to make the meaning of something clearer by using examples, pictures, etc.
ex: To illustrate my point, let me tell you a little story
ex: Last year's sales figures are illustrated in Figure 2
ex: This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making
ex: First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips
ex: Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine
ex: Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed
ex: Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities
ex: The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt
ex: As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away
ex: At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper
ex: The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls
ex: illustrate something 
ex: illustrate how, what, etc 
ex: illustrate that

ex: Thank you very much indeed!

word: indicate

def: to show that something is true or exists

ex: Our results indicate how misleading it could be to rely on this method

ex: indicate something 
ex: A red sky at night often indicates good weather the next day
ex: indicate that 
ex: Early results indicate that the mayor will get a second term

ex: indicate (to somebody) (that)

ex: indicate something (to somebody) 
ex: He indicated his willingness to cooperate
ex: indicate whether, when, etc 
ex: Has she indicated yet whether she would like to be involved? Thesaurusdeclarestate indicate announceThese words all mean to say something, usually firmly and clearly and often in public

ex: The painting was declared (to be) a forgery

ex: indicate something

def: used to refer to a baby, especially one whose sex is not known
ex: Her baby's due next month

def: used to refer to a fact or situation that is already known or happening
ex: When the factory closes, it will mean 500 people losing their jobs
ex: Yes, I was at home on Sunday
ex: Stop it, you're hurting me!5

def: used to identify a person
ex: It's your mother on the phone
ex: Hello, Peter, it's Mike here
ex: Hi, it's me! 
ex: Was it you who put these books on my desk?6

def: used in the position of the subject or object of a verb when the real subject or object is at the end of the sentence
ex: Does it matter what color it is? 
ex: It's impossible to get there in time
ex: It's no use shouting
ex: She finds it boring at home
ex: It appears that the two leaders are holding secret talks
ex: I find it strange that she doesn't want to go

def: used in the position of the subject of a verb when you are talking about time, the date, distance, the weather, etc.
ex: It's ten after twelve
ex: It's our anniversary
ex: It's two miles to the beach
ex: It's a long time since they left
ex: It was raining this morning
ex: It's quite warm at the moment

def: used when you are talking about a situation
ex: If it's convenient I can come tomorrow
ex: It's good to talk
ex: I like it here

def: used to emphasize any part of a sentence
ex: It's Jim who's the smart one
ex: It's Spain that they're going to, not Portugal
ex: It was three weeks later that he heard the news

def: exactly what is needed
ex: In this business, either you've got it or you don't

word: just

def: exactly
ex: This jacket is just my size
ex: This gadget is just the thing for getting those nails out
ex: Just my luck (= the sort of bad luck I usually have)
ex: You're just in time
ex: just like 
ex: She looks just like her mother
ex: just what 
ex: It's just what I wanted! 
ex: just as 
ex: It's just as I thought
ex: just as 

def: at the same moment as
ex: The clock struck six just as I arrived
ex: just as good, nice, easily, etc

def: no less than; equally
ex: She's just as smart as her sister
ex: You can get there just as cheaply by plane
ex: (only) just 
ex: just after, before, under, etc

def: by a small amount
ex: I got here just after nine
ex: I only just caught the train
ex: Inflation fell to just over 4 percent

def: used to say that you/someone did something very recently
ex: I've just heard the news
ex: When you arrived he had only just left
ex: She has just been telling us about her trip to Rome
ex: I just saw him a moment ago

def: at this/that moment; now
ex: I'm just finishing my book
ex: I was just beginning to enjoy myself when we had to leave
ex: just about/going to do something 

def: going to do something only a few moments from now or then
ex: The water's just about to boil
ex: I was just going to tell you when you interrupted

def: simply
ex: It was just an ordinary day
ex: Ican't just drop all my commitments
ex: This essay is just not good enough
ex: I didn't mean to upset you
ex: This is not just another disaster movieit's a masterpiece
ex: Just because you're older than me doesn't mean you know everything

def: really; completely
ex: The food was just wonderful! 
ex: I can just imagine his reaction

def: only
ex: just (for something) 
ex: I decided to learn Japanese just for fun
ex: just (to do something) 
ex: I waited an hour just to see you
ex: There is just one method that might work
ex: Can I help you? No thanks,I'm just looking

def: used in orders to get someone's attention, give permission, etc.
ex: Just listen to what I'm saying! 
ex: Just help yourselves!12

def: used to make a polite request, excuse, etc.
ex: Could you just help me with this box, please? 
ex: I've just got a few things to do first
ex: could/might/may just 

def: used to show a slight possibility that something is true or will happen
ex: Try his home numberhe might just be there

def: used to agree with someone
ex: He's very pompous

ex: brutal killings see also mercy killing Topic CollocationsCrimecommitting a crime	commit a crime/a murder/a violent assault/a brutal killing/an armed robbery/fraud/perjury	be involved in terrorism/a suspected arson attack/human smuggling/human trafficking	engage/participate in criminal activity/illegal practices/acts of mindless vandalism	steal somebody's wallet/purse/watch/cell phone	rob a bank/a person/a tourist	break into/burglarize a house/a home/an apartment/an office	hijack a plane/ship/bus	smuggle drugs/weapons/arms/people/immigrants	launder (drug) money (through something)	forge documents/certificates/passports	take/accept/pay somebody/offer (somebody) a bribe	run a phishing scam/an e-mail scam/an Internet scamfighting crime	combat/fight crime/terrorism/drug trafficking/corruption	prevent/stop credit-card fraud/child abuse/software piracy	deter/stop criminals/burglars/thieves/shoplifters/vandals	reduce/tackle/crack down on gun/violent/street/property crime	foil a bank robbery/a terrorist plot	help/support/protect the victims of crimeinvestigating crime	report a crime/a theft/a rape/an attack/an incident to the police	witness a crime/an attack/a murder/an incident	investigate a murder/a homicide/a burglary/a robbery/the alleged incident	conduct/launch/pursue/open an investigation (into)	investigate/reopen a criminal/murder case	examine/investigate/find fingerprints at the crime scene/the scene of crime	collect/gather forensic evidence/physical evidence	uncover/discover new evidence/a fraud/a scam/a plot/a conspiracy/political corruption/a cache of weapons	describe/identify a suspect/the culprit/the perpetrator/the assailant/the attacker	question/interrogate a suspect/witness	solve/crack the case	 more collocations at justiceIdioms make a killing (informal)

word: kind

def: a group of people or things that are the same in some way; a particular variety or type
ex: three kinds of cake 
ex: music of all/various/different kinds 
ex: Exercises of this kind are very popular
ex: What kind of house do you live in? 
ex: They sell all kinds of things
ex: The school is the first of its kind in the city
ex: She isn't that kind of girl
ex: The regions differ in size, but not in kind
ex: I need to buy paper and pencils, that kind of thing
ex: I'll never have that kind of money (= as much money as that)
ex: Would you like a drink of some kind? Grammarkind / type / sortUse the singular (kind/type/sort) or plural (kinds/types/sorts) depending on the word you use before them:
ex: each/one/every kind of animal 
ex: all/many/other types of animalsKind/type/sort of is followed by a singular or uncountable noun:
ex: This type of question often appears on the test
ex: That sort of behavior is not acceptable
ex: These types of questions often appear on the test
ex: These sorts of behavior are not acceptable
ex: These types of question often appear on the test
ex: These kind of things dont happen in real life
ex: The shelf was full of the sort of books I like to read
ex: He faced the same kind of problems as his predecessor
ex: There are many different types of animal on the island
ex: What kind of camera is this? 
ex: What kind/kinds of cameras do you sell? 
ex: There were three kinds of cakes/cake on the plate

ex: She spoke kindly to them

def: used to ask or tell someone to do something, especially when you are annoyed
ex: Kindly leave me alone! 
ex: Visitors are kindly requested to sign the book

word: know

def: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
ex: know something 
ex: Do you know his address? 
ex: The cause of the fire is not yet known
ex: All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her)
ex: know (that) 
ex: I know (that) people's handwriting changes as they get older
ex: it is known that 
ex: It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
ex: know where, what, etc 
ex: I knew where he was hiding
ex: I didn't know what he was talking about
ex: know (of/about something) 
ex: You've got a flat tire
ex: What's the answer? I don't know
ex: There's no one home
ex: You know about Amanda's baby, don't you? 
ex: I don't know about you, butI'm ready for something to eat
ex: I know of at least two people who did the same thing
ex: Is anyone else coming? Not that I know of
ex: Isn't that his car? I wouldn't know
ex: What are you two whispering about? You don't want to know
ex: know to do something 
ex: Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first? 
ex: know somebody/something to be/do something 
ex: We know her to be honest
ex: Two women are known to have died

def: to realize, understand, or be aware of something
ex: know (that) 
ex: As soon as I walked in the room I knew (that) something was wrong
ex: She knew she was dying
ex: know what, how, etc 
ex: I knew perfectly well what she meant
ex: I know exactly how you feel
ex: know (something) 
ex: This case is hopeless and he knows it (= although he will not admit it)
ex: Martin was lying the whole time

def: to feel certain about something
ex: know (that) 
ex: He knew (that) he could trust her
ex: I know it's here somewhere! 
ex: I know things will turn out all right
ex: I don't know that I can finish it by next week
ex: I just knew that it was something I wanted to do
ex: know (something) 
ex: You were rightsomeone's been spreading rumors about you
ex: She's the worst player in the team
ex: know somebody/something

ex: I've known David for 20 years

ex: She was a secretary when I first knew her
ex: She's very nice when you get to know her

ex: I don't know anyone in Albuquerque
ex: I know Savannah well
ex: Do you know the play (= have you seen or read it before)? 
ex: The new rules could mean the end of football as we know it (= in the form that we are familiar with)

def: to think that someone or something is a particular type of person or thing or has particular characteristics
ex: know somebody/something as something 
ex: It's known as the most dangerous part of the city
ex: know somebody/something for something 
ex: She is best known for her work on the human brain
ex: know somebody/something to be/do something 
ex: He's known to be an outstanding physicist
ex: know somebody/something as something [usually passive]

ex: Ascorbic acid is more commonly known as Vitamin C
ex: Peter Wilson, also known as the Tiger
ex: know somebody/something

ex: I hope we have taught our children to know right from wrong

ex: a laundry vanIdioms air your dirty laundry/linen in public (disapproving)

word: law

def: the whole system of rules that everyone in a country or society must obey
ex: If they entered the building they would be breaking the law
ex: In this city, it is against the law to sleep in an abandoned building
ex: Defense attorneys can use any means within the law to get their client off
ex: Anyone who operates a motor vehicle is required by law to have a driver's license
ex: The reforms recently became law
ex: Do not think you are above the law (= think that you cannot be punished by the law)
ex: the need for better law enforcement (humorous) 
ex: Kate's word was law in the Brown household

def: a particular branch of the law
ex: corporate/international/tax, etc

def: a rule that deals with a particular crime, agreement, etc.
ex: law (against something) 
ex: a law against the hiring of illegal immigrants 
ex: law (on something) 
ex: The government has introduced some tough new laws on food hygiene
ex: strict gun laws 
ex: a federal/state law 
ex: to pass a law (= officially make it part of the system of laws) (informal) 
ex: There ought to be a law against it! see also bylaw, lemon law subject/profession4 [uncountable] 

def: the study of the law as a subject at a university, etc.; the profession of being a lawyer
ex: Jane is studying law
ex: He's in law school
ex: What made you go into law? 
ex: a law firm police5the law [singular] 

def: used to refer to the police and the legal system
ex: Jim is always getting into trouble with the law
ex: She was well known for her brushes with the law

def: one of the rules that control an organization or activity
ex: the laws of the Roman Catholic Church 
ex: The first law of kung fu is to defend yourself
ex: the laws of tennis 
ex: the laws of war of good behavior7 [countable] 

def: a rule for good behavior or how you should behave in a particular place or situation
ex: moral laws 
ex: the unspoken law of the street in business/nature/science8 [countable] 

def: the fact that something always happens in the same way in an activity or in nature
ex: the law of supply and demand 
ex: the law of gravity9 [countable] 

def: a scientific rule that someone has stated to explain a natural process
ex: the first law of thermodynamics see also legal, legalize, legislate, Murphy's Law, Parkinson's lawIdioms be a law unto yourself

word: matter

def: a subject or situation that you must consider or deal with
ex: It's a private matter
ex: They had important matters to discuss
ex: She may need your help with some business matters
ex: I always consulted him on matters of policy
ex: It's a matter for the police (= for them to deal with)

ex: It was no easy matter getting him to change his mind
ex: It should have been a simple matter to check
ex: And then there's the little matter of the fifty dollars you owe me
ex: It was a matter of some concern to most of those present (= something they were worried about)
ex: I did not feel that we ever got to the heart of the matter (= the most important part)
ex: And that is the crux of the matter (= the most important thing about the situation)

def: the present situation, or the situation that you are talking about
ex: Unfortunately, there is nothing we can do to improve matters
ex: I'd forgotten the keys, which didn't help matters
ex: And then,to make matters worse, his parents turned up
ex: I decided to take matters into my own hands (= deal with the situation myself)
ex: Matters came to a head (= the situation became very difficult) with his resignation

ex: What's the matter?Is there something wrong? 
ex: Is anything the matter? 
ex: matter with somebody/something 
ex: Is something the matter with Bob? He seems very down
ex: There's something the matter with my eyes
ex: We bought a new TV

ex: What on earth was the matter with her, she wondered

def: a situation that involves something or depends on something
ex: Learning to drive is all a matter of coordination
ex: Planning a project is just a matter of working out the right order to do things in
ex: That's not a problem
ex: Some people prefer the older version to the new one
ex: She resigned as a matter of principle
ex: The health department has to deal with this as a matter of urgency
ex: Just as a matter of interest (= because it is interesting, not because it is important), how much did you pay for it? 
ex: I think this is the best so far

def: physical substance in general that everything in the world consists of; not mind or spirit
ex: to study the properties of matter6[uncountable] 

def: a substance or things of a particular sort
ex: Add plenty of organic matter to improve the soil
ex: elimination of waste matter from the body 
ex: She didn't approve of their choice of reading matter

word: maybe

ex: We go there maybe once or twice a month

def: used when making a suggestion
ex: I thought maybe we could go together
ex: Maybe you should tell her
ex: Maybe we can meet for lunch next week sometime

def: used to agree with someone, and to add more information that should be thought about
ex: You should stop work when you have the baby

def: used when replying to a question or an idea, when you are not sure whether to agree or disagree
ex: I think he should resign

ex: Did I mention going to see Vicky on Sunday? see also above-mentioned, aforementioned Thesaurusmentionrefer to somebody/something speak of/about somebody/something cite quoteThese words all mean to write or speak about someone or something, often in order to give an example or prove something

ex: I promised not to refer to the matter again

word: might

def: used as the past tense of 
ex: He said he might come tomorrow

def: used when showing that something is or was possible
ex: He might get there in time, but I can't be sure
ex: I know Vicky doesn't like the job, but I might not find it too bad
ex: The pills might have helped him, if only he'd taken them regularly
ex: He might say that now (= it is true that he does), but he'll probably change his mind

def: used to make a polite suggestion
ex: You might try calling the help desk
ex: I thought we might go to the zoo on Saturday

def: used to ask for information
ex: How might we improve the plans? 
ex: And who might she be?5

def: used to show that you are annoyed about something that someone could do or could have done
ex: I think you might at least offer to help! 
ex: Honestly, you might have told me!6

def: used to say that you are not surprised by something
ex: I might have guessed it was you!7

def: used to emphasize that an important point has been made
ex: And where is the money coming from? You might well ask! Grammarmodal verbsThe modal verbs are can, could, may, might, must, ought to, shall, should, will, and would
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results

ex: a mild form of the disease

ex: Use a soap that is mild to the skin

ex: the mildest winter since records began 
ex: a mild climate compare hard3(of feelings)

ex: mild irritation/amusement/disapproval 
ex: a mild state of shock

ex: a mild woman, who never shouted5 (of a flavor) 

def: not strong, spicy, or bitter
ex: mild salsa 
ex: mild cheese opposite hot mildness

ex: My car gets 35 miles to the gallon

ex: miles and miles of desert 
ex: There isn't a house for miles around here
ex: I'm not walkingit's miles away

ex: She's taller than you by a mile

ex: a four-minute mileIdioms be miles away (informal)

def: a person who is very intelligent

word: much

def: used with uncountable nouns, especially in negative sentences to mean a large amount of something, or after how to ask about the amount of something. It is also used with as, so, and too.
ex: I don't have much money with me
ex: Got any money? Not much
ex: How much water do you need? 
ex: How much is it (= What does it cost)? 
ex: Take as much time as you like
ex: There was so much traffic that we were an hour late
ex: I've got far too much to do
ex: I lay awake for much of the night
ex: There was much discussion about the reasons for the failure

-----

word: must

def: used to say that something is necessary or very important (sometimes involving a rule or a law)
ex: All visitors must report to reception
ex: Cars must not park in front of the entrance (= it is not allowed)
ex: I must ask you not to do that again
ex: You mustn't say things like that
ex: I must go to the bank and get some money
ex: I must admit (= I feel that I should admit) I was surprised it cost so little
ex: Must you always question everything I say? (= it is annoying) 
ex: Do we have to finish this today? Yes, you must
ex: No, you don't have to

def: used to say that something is likely or logical
ex: You must be hungry after all that walking
ex: He must have known (= surely he knew) what she wanted
ex: I'm sorry, she's not here

def: used to recommend that someone do something because you think it is a good idea
ex: You simply must read this book
ex: We must get together soon for lunch
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results
ex: You have to be home by 11 oclock
ex: I have to wash the car tomorrow
ex: I have to collect the children from school at 3 oclock
ex: All nurses must wear uniform
ex: Changes must be recorded in the log book
ex: I had to wait half an hour for a bus
ex: Well have to borrow the money we need
ex: I have to go to the dentist tomorrow
ex: Do the children have to wear uniforms?In negative sentences, both must not and dont have to are used, but with different meanings
ex: Employees must not smoke in the building
ex: You mustnt leave the gate open
ex: You dont have to pay for the tickets in advance
ex: She doesnt have to work on weekends
ex: He has (got) to be the worst actor on TV!If you are talking about the past, use must have:
ex: Your trip must have been fun!Idioms if you must (do something)

word: my

def: of or belonging to the speaker or writer
ex: Where's my passport? 
ex: My feet are cold

def: used in exclamations to express surprise, etc.
ex: My goodness! Look at the time!3

def: used when addressing someone, to show affection
ex: my dear/darling/love4

def: used when addressing someone that you consider to have a lower status than you
ex: My dear girl, you're wrong

ex: I needed space to be myself (= not be influenced by other people)

def: used to emphasize the fact that the speaker is doing something
ex: I'll speak to her myself
ex: I myself do not agree

word: near

def: a short distance away
ex: His house is very near
ex: Where's the nearest bank? Which Word?next / nearest	(The)next means after this/that one in time or in a series of events, places, or people:
ex: When is your next appointment? 
ex: Take a left at the next traffic light
ex: Whos next?(The)nearest means closest in space:
ex: Wheres the nearest grocery store?	Notice the difference between the prepositions nearest to and next to:
ex: Janets sitting nearest to the window (= of all the people in the room)
ex: Sarahs sitting next to the window (= right beside it)

def: a short time away in the future
ex: The conflict is unlikely to be resolved in the near future (= very soon)

def: coming next after someone or something
ex: She has a 12-point lead over her nearest rival

def: similar; most similar
ex: He was the nearest thing to (= the person most like) a father she had ever had

def: close to being someone or something
ex: The election proved to be a near disaster for the party
ex: a near impossibility6
ex: near relative/relation

word: need

ex: It gave me an excuse to drive instead of walking

-----

word: original

def: existing at the beginning of a particular period, process, or activity
ex: The room still has many of its original features
ex: I think you should go back to your original plan
ex: At the end of the lease, the land will be returned to the original owner
ex: The original intention was to record about 80 speakers, divided equally between males and females

def: new and interesting in a way that is different from anything that has existed before; able to produce new and interesting ideas
ex: an original idea 
ex: That's not a very original suggestion
ex: an original thinker 
ex: the product of a highly original mind3 [usually before noun] 

def: painted, written, etc. by the artist rather than copied
ex: an original painting by a local artist 
ex: The original manuscript has been lost
ex: Only original documents (= not photocopies) will be accepted as proof of status

-----

word: originally

def: used to describe the situation that existed at the beginning of a particular period or activity, especially before something was changed
ex: The school was originally very small
ex: She comes originally from New York
ex: Originally, we had intended to go to Italy, but then we won the trip to Greece

-----

word: other

def: used to refer to people or things that are additional to or different from people or things that have been mentioned or are known about
ex: Mr
ex: Are there any other questions? 
ex: I can't see you nowsome other time, maybe
ex: Two buildings were destroyed and many others damaged in the blast
ex: This option is preferable to any other
ex: Some designs are better than others

def: used to refer to the second of two people or things
ex: My other sister is a doctor
ex: One son went to live in Australia and the other one was killed in a car crash
ex: He raised one arm and then the other
ex: You must ask one or other of your parents
ex: You'll have to ask my other half (= husband, wife, or partner)

def: used to refer to the remaining people or things in a group
ex: I'll wear my other shoesthese are dirty
ex: I like this one
ex: I went swimming while the others played tennis

def: used to refer to a place, direction, etc. that is the opposite to where you are, are going, etc.
ex: I work on the other side of town
ex: He crashed into a car coming the other way
ex: He found me, not the other way around

-----

word: otherwise

def: used to state what the result would be if something did not happen or if the situation were different
ex: My parents lent me the money
ex: Shut the window, otherwise it'll get too cold in here
ex: We're committed to the project

def: apart from that
ex: There was some music playing upstairs
ex: He was slightly bruised but otherwise unhurt

def: in a different way to the way mentioned; differently
ex: Bismarck,otherwise known asthe Iron Chancellor 
ex: It is not permitted to sell or otherwise distribute copies of past examination papers
ex: You know what this is about
ex: I wanted to see him but he was otherwise engaged (= doing something else)

-----

word: ought to

def: used to say what is the right thing to do
ex: They ought to apologize
ex: Should I to write to say thank you? Yes, I think you ought (to)
ex: They ought to have apologized (= but they didn't)
ex: Such things ought not to be allowed
ex: He oughtn't to have been driving so fast
ex: You should take the baby to the doctors
ex: I ought to give up smoking
ex: Should we call the doctor?Had better can also be used to say what is the best thing to do in a situation that is happening now:
ex: Wed better hurry or well miss the train
ex: She should have asked for some help
ex: You ought to have been more careful
ex: You shouldnt drive so fast
ex: Im sorry, I shouldnt have lost my temper

def: used to say what you expect or would like to happen
ex: Children ought to be able to read by the age of 7
ex: Nurses ought to earn more

def: used to say what you advise or recommend
ex: We ought to be leaving now
ex: This is delicious
ex: You ought to have come to the meeting

def: used to say what has probably happened or is probably true
ex: If he started out at nine, he ought to be here by now
ex: That ought to be enough food for the four of us
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results

def: a unit for measuring weight, 1/16 of a pound, equal to 28.35 grams
ex: ounce of something (informal) (used especially with negatives) 

def: a very small quantity of something
ex: There's not an ounce of truth in her story

ex: What percent of the population is overweight? Grammarexpressing percentagesPercentages (=numbers of percent) are written in words as twenty-five percent and in numbers as 25%
ex: 90% of the land is cultivated
ex: Eighty percent of the work force is against the strike
ex: 65% of children play computer games

-----

word: percentage

def: the number, amount, or rate of something, expressed as if it is part of a total which is 100; a part or share of a whole
ex: What percentage of the population is overweight? 
ex: A high percentage of the female staff works part-time
ex: Interest rates are expected to rise by one percentage point (= one percent)
ex: The figure is expressed as a percentage
ex: The results were analyzed in percentage terms

def: a share of the profits of something
ex: He gets a percentage for every car sold

-----

word: perfect

def: having everything that is necessary; complete and without faults or weaknesses
ex: in perfect condition 
ex: a perfect set of teeth 
ex: Well I'm sorrybut nobody's perfect (= used when someone has criticized you)

def: completely correct; exact and accurate
ex: She speaks perfect English
ex: a perfect copy/fit/match 
ex: What perfect timing! see also letter-perfect3

def: the best of its kind
ex: a perfect example of the painter's early style 
ex: the perfect crime (= one in which the criminal is never discovered)4

def: excellent; very good
ex: The weather was perfect
ex: The rooms are excellent value at $20 a night
ex: He speaks excellent English
ex: You can all come? Excellent!outstanding extremely good
ex: an outstanding achievement 
ex: She's an outstanding dancer
ex: Conditions were perfect for walking
ex: She came up with the perfect excuse
ex: The facilities at the hotel are superb
ex: perfect for somebody/something 

def: exactly right for someone or something
ex: It was a perfect day for a picnic
ex: She's the perfect candidate for the job
ex: Will 2:30 be OK for you? Yes, that will be perfect

def: total; complete
ex: I don't know himhe's a perfect stranger

def: connected with the form of a verb that consists of part of the verb 
ex: I have eaten is the present perfect tense of the verb to eat, I had eaten is the past perfect, and I will have eaten is the future perfect

word: perfectly

def: completely
ex: It's perfectly normal to feel like this
ex: It's perfectly good as it is (= it doesn't need changing)
ex: You know perfectly well what I mean
ex: To be perfectly honest, I didn't want to go anyway
ex: He stood perfectly still until the danger had passed
ex: Do you understand? Perfectly
ex: How perfectly awful! 
ex: They're perfectly within their rights to ask to see the report

def: in a perfect way
ex: The TV works perfectly now
ex: It fits perfectly

ex: perform (something)

ex: The play was first performed in 2007
ex: I'd like to hear it performed live
ex: to perform on the flute 
ex: I'm looking forward to seeing you perform
ex: perform (well/badly/poorly)

ex: The engine seems to be performing well

ex: If he performs (= performs well) then I believe the Cubs can win
ex: She performed less well in the second test

word: perhaps

def: possibly
ex: Are you going to come? Perhaps
ex: Perhaps he's forgotten

def: used when you want to make a statement or an opinion less definite
ex: This is perhaps his best novel to date

def: used when making a rough estimate
ex: a change that could affect perhaps 20% of the population4

def: used when you agree or accept something unwillingly, or do not want to say strongly that you disapprove
ex: You could do it yourself

def: used when making a polite request, offer, or suggestion
ex: Perhaps it would be better if you came back tomorrow
ex: I think perhaps you've had enough to drink tonight
ex: Perhaps you'd like to have a shower before the others arrive
ex: Perhaps you would be good enough to let him know we are on our way
ex: Most cybercrime involves traditional crimes, such as theft and fraud, being committed in new ways

def: a short distance
ex: She lives down the road a piece from here
ex: a piece of paper/wood/string/cake/fruit/meat/work/research/advice	Bit can be used with abstract uncountable nouns:
ex: a bit of luck/confidence/attention	A slice is a thin, flat piece:
ex: a slice of bread/cake/salami/cheese/pie/apple(figurative)
ex: a slice of life	A chunk is a thick, solid piece:
ex: a chunk of cheese/bread/rock 
ex: a chunk of land (= a fairly large piece)	A lump is a piece of something solid without any particular shape:
ex: a lump of coal/clay	A fragment is a very small piece of something that is broken or damaged:
ex: fragments of glass(figurative)
ex: fragments of conversation
ex: a fragment of the story	A speck is a tiny piece of powder:
ex: a speck of dust/dirtYou can also say:
ex: a speck of light	Drop is used with liquids:
ex: a drop of water/rain/blood/milk/whiskey	A pinch is as much as you can hold between your finger and thumb:
ex: a pinch of salt/cinnamon	A portion is enough for one person:
ex: a portion of chickenIdioms bits and pieces (informal)

def: a method of doing or making something, especially one that is used in industry
ex: manufacturing processes 
ex: a new process for rustproofing car bodies Language Bankprocessdescribing a process	
ex: This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making
ex: First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips
ex: Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine
ex: Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed
ex: Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities
ex: The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt
ex: As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away
ex: At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper
ex: The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls

word: really

def: used to say what is actually the fact or the truth about something
ex: What do you really think about it? 
ex: Tell me what really happened
ex: They are not really my aunt and uncle
ex: I can't believe I am really going to meet the President

def: used to emphasize something you are saying or an opinion you are giving
ex: I want to help, I really do
ex: Now I really must go
ex: I really don't mind
ex: He really likes you
ex: Ireally and truly am in love this time

def: used to emphasize an adjective or adverb
ex: a really hot fire 
ex: I'm really sorry
ex: She was driving really fast

def: used, often in negative sentences, to reduce the force of something you are saying
ex: I don't really agree with that
ex: It doesn't really matter
ex: Did you enjoy the book? Not really
ex: We've done well, really

def: used in questions and negative sentences when you want someone to say no
ex: Do you really expect me to believe that? 
ex: I don't really need to go, do I?6

def: used to express interest in or surprise at what someone is saying
ex: We're going to Japan next month
ex: She's resigned

def: used to show that you disapprove of something someone has done
ex: Really, you could have told us before

ex: They are considered a high-risk group

ex: How do you view your position within the company? View has the same meaning as regard and consider but is slightly less frequent and slightly less formal

def: used for emphasis to show that someone or something is an exact or clear example of the thing mentioned
ex: The whole thing was a regular disaster

word: result

def: a thing that is caused or produced because of something else
ex: She died as a result of her injuries
ex: The failure of the company was a direct result of bad management
ex: He made one big mistake, and, as a result, lost his job
ex: The farm was flooded,with the result that most of the harvest was lost
ex: The end result (= the final one) of her hard work was a place in medical school
ex: This book is the result of 25 years of research
ex: The number of people with diabetes is growing, partly because of an increase in levels of obesity
ex: The number of overweight children has increased dramatically in recent years, largely as a result of changes in diet and lifestyle
ex: The increase in childhood obesity is largely due to/the result of changes in lifestyle and diet over the last twenty years
ex: Many obese children are bullied at school on account of their weight
ex: Part of the problem with treating childhood obesity stems from the fact that parents do not always recognize that their children are obese
ex: Childhood obesity may be caused by genetic factors as well as environmental ones
ex: One consequence of changes in diet over recent years has been a dramatic increase in cases of childhood obesity
ex: Many parents today do not have time to cook healthy meals for their children
ex: Many children spend their free time watching TV instead of playing outside
ex: Last year, junk food was banned in schools
ex: result (of something) 

def: the final score or the name of the winner in a sports event, competition, election, etc.
ex: They will announce the result of the vote tonight
ex: the election results 
ex: the football results of test/research3[countable]

word: right

def: morally good or acceptable; correct according to law or a person's duty

ex: Is it true that she's leaving?right that is true and cannot be doubted as a fact:

def: correct for a particular situation or thing, or for a particular person

def: in a normal or good enough condition
ex: I just don't feel right today (= I feel sick)

ex: Things aren't right between her parents

word: rightly

def: for a good reason
ex: The school was rightly proud of its many successful graduates

def: in a correct or accurate way
ex: Rightly or wrongly, many older people are afraid of violence in the streets
ex: As she rightly pointed out, the illness can affect adults as well as children
ex: I can't rightly say what happened
ex: I don't rightly know where he's gone
ex: If I remember rightly, there's a bus at six o'clock
ex: He did it right
ex: Did I spell your name right?Rightly cannot be used like this
ex: Is your name spelled correctly?	The usual meaning of rightly is for a good reason and it is used most often in the phrase and rightly so:
ex: She disagrees with the policy, and rightly so
ex: As you rightly say, we have a serious problem

ex: Sad to say (= unfortunately), the house has now been demolished

ex: It's a sad fact that many of those killed were children
ex: It's a sad reflection on life that it takes danger and suffering to bring people closer together

def: boring or not fashionable
ex: You sad old man
ex: You'd have to be sad to wear a shirt like that

def: in poor condition
ex: The salad consisted of a few leaves of sad-looking lettuce

ex: The doctor told me to stay in bed

word: should

def: used to show what is right, appropriate, etc., especially when criticizing someone's actions
ex: You shouldn't drink and drive
ex: He should have been more careful
ex: A present for me? You shouldn't have! (= used to thank someone politely)2 

def: used to say that you expect something is true or will happen
ex: We should arrive before dark
ex: I should have finished the book by Friday
ex: The roads should be less crowded today

def: used to say that something that was expected has not happened
ex: It should be snowing now, according to the weather forecast
ex: The bus should have arrived ten minutes ago

def: used to refer to a possible event or situation
ex: If you should change your mind, just let me know
ex: In case you should need any help, here's my number
ex: Should anyone call (= if anyone calls), please tell them I'm busy

def: used after 
ex: She recommended that I should take some time off
ex: She recommended that I take some time off
ex: why, how, who, what should somebody/something do 

def: used to refuse something or to show that you are annoyed at a request; used to express surprise about an event or a situation
ex: Why should I help him? He's never done anything for me
ex: How should I know where to find you? 
ex: I got on the bus and who should be sitting in front of me but Tony!7 

def: used after 
ex: I'm anxious that we should allow plenty of time
ex: I find it astonishing that he should be so rude to you

def: used with 
ex: I should imagine it will take about three hours
ex: Is this enough food for everyone? I should think so
ex: Will it matter? I shouldn't think so

def: used for expressing strong agreement
ex: I know it's expensive but it will last for years
ex: Nobody will oppose it

def: used to tell someone that something would amuse or surprise them if they saw or experienced it
ex: You should have seen her face when she found out! Grammarmodal verbsThe modal verbs are can, could, may, might, must, ought to, shall, should, will, and would
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results
ex: You should take the baby to the doctors
ex: I ought to give up smoking
ex: Should we call the doctor?Had better can also be used to say what is the best thing to do in a situation that is happening now:
ex: Wed better hurry or well miss the train
ex: She should have asked for some help
ex: You ought to have been more careful
ex: You shouldnt drive so fast
ex: Im sorry, I shouldnt have lost my temper
ex: I said Id (I would) be late
ex: Hed (he would) like to have been an actor
ex: Id (I would) really prefer coffee
ex: We should really go and visit them soon
ex: You should have seen it!Check pronunciation: should

ex: It is necessary to carry out a trial on a statistically significant number of individuals

ex: The small sample size is statistically insignificant
ex: Seemingly insignificant scratches in glass may cause breakage
ex: In the test, high variability resulted in a lack of statistical significance
ex: There are two very different ways to assess the broader significance of these events
ex: Actual markets differ significantly from perfectly competitive markets
ex: Significantly lower numbers of seals were observed at low tide

ex: Stir the paint with a piece of wood or something similar
ex: The two methods gave qualitatively similar patterns
ex: Our results are similar to the research findings outlined in the literature review
ex: They spoke a language similar to that of the Aztecs
ex: If the model has too few classes, highly dissimilar plants are treated as if they were identical
ex: Hayek's earliest view was not very dissimilar from Schumpeter's
ex: This finding also bears a remarkable similarity to other studies that examined educational performance
ex: Although the microelectronics and biotechnology industries share certain similarities, the two differ in numerous ways
ex: The findings of our study call attention to a striking similarity between both groups

ex: Husband and wife were similarly successful in their chosen careers

ex: Can you speak slower/more slowly?In formal language, and especially in writing, slowly is used as the adverb form

word: smash

def: to break something, or to be broken, violently and noisily into many pieces
ex: Several windows had been smashed
ex: He smashed the radio to pieces
ex: The glass bowl smashed into a thousand pieces

def: to move with a lot of force against something solid; to make something do this

ex: the sound of waves smashing against the rocks 
ex: The car smashed into a tree

ex: Mark smashed his fist down on the desk
ex: I was terrified that the plane would crash
ex: The car skidded and slammed into a tree
ex: The car and the van collided head-on in thick fog
ex: The thieves smashed a stolen car through the store's display
ex: We're going to crash, aren't we?In this meaning slam and smash always take a preposition:We're going to slam/smash, aren't we?They are used for a much wider range of things than just vehicles
ex: She turned the corner in the hallway and crashed into the soda machine

word: so

def: to such a great degree
ex: Don't look so angry
ex: There's no need to worry so
ex: so  (that) 
ex: She spoke so quietly (that) I could hardly hear her
ex: so  as to do something 
ex: I'm not so stupid as to believe that
ex: Would you be so kind as to lock the door when you leave?2 

def: very; extremely
ex: I'm so glad to see you
ex: We have so much to do
ex: Their attitude is so very upper-class
ex: The article was just so much (= nothing but) nonsense
ex: He sat there ever so quietly
ex: I do love it so
ex: not so  (as) (used in comparisons) 

def: not to the same degree
ex: I haven't enjoyed myself so much for a long time
ex: It wasn't so good as last time
ex: It's not so easy as you'd think
ex: He was not so quick a learner as his brother
ex: It's not so much a hobby as a career (= more like a career than a hobby)
ex: Off she went without so much as (= without even) a goodbye

def: used to show the size, amount, or number of something
ex: The fish was about so big (= said when using your hands to show the size)
ex: There are only so many (= only a limited number of) hours in a day

def: used to refer back to something that has already been mentioned
ex: Is he coming? I hope so
ex: Did they mind? Idon't think so
ex: If she notices, she never says so
ex: I might be away next week
ex: We are very busyso much so that we won't be able to take time off this year
ex: Programs are expensive, and even more so if you have to keep altering them
ex: I hear that you're a writeris that so (= is that true)? 
ex: He thinks I dislike him but that just isn't so
ex: George is going to help me, or so he says (= that is what he says)
ex: They asked me to call them and Idid so (= I called)

def: also
ex: Times have changed and so have I
ex: I prefer the first version
ex: I'm not hungry

def: used to agree that something is true, especially when you are surprised
ex: You were there, too
ex: There's another one

def: used, often with a negative, before adjectives and noun phrases to emphasize something that you are saying
ex: He is so not the right person for you
ex: That is so not cool

def: used, especially by children, to say that what someone says is not the case and the opposite is true
ex: You're not telling the truth, are you? I am, so!10

def: used when you are showing someone how to do something or telling them how something happened
ex: Stand with your arms out, so
ex: So it was that he finally returned home

word: sort

def: a group or type of people or things that are similar in a particular way
ex: What sort of music do you like? Oh,all sorts

ex: There were snackspeanuts, olives,that sort of thing
ex: There are all sorts of activities (= many different ones) for kids at the campsite
ex: What sort of price did you want to pay? (= approximately how much) Grammarkind / type / sortUse the singular (kind/type/sort) or plural (kinds/types/sorts) depending on the word you use before them:
ex: each/one/every kind of animal 
ex: all/many/other types of animalsKind/type/sort of is followed by a singular or uncountable noun:
ex: This type of question often appears on the test
ex: That sort of behavior is not acceptable
ex: These types of questions often appear on the test

word: stage

def: a period or state that something or someone passes through while developing or making progress
ex: This technology is still in its early stages
ex: The children are at different stages of development
ex: The product is at the design stage
ex: People tend to work hard at this stage of life
ex: At one stage it looked as though they would win
ex: Don't worry about the baby not wanting to leave youit's a stage they go through

def: a separate part that a process, etc. is divided into
ex: We did the first stage of the trip by train
ex: The police are building up a picture of the incident stage by stage
ex: The pay increase will be introduced in stages (= not all at once)
ex: We can take the argument one stage further
ex: This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making
ex: First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips
ex: Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine
ex: Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed
ex: Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities
ex: The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt
ex: As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away
ex: At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper
ex: The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls

def: a raised area, usually in a theater, etc. where actors, dancers, etc. perform
ex: The audience threw flowers onto the stage
ex: There were more than 50 people on stage in one scene
ex: They marched off stage to the sound of trumpets

def: the theater and the world of acting as a form of entertainment
ex: His parents didn't want him to go on the stage (= to be an actor)
ex: She was a popular star of stage and screen (= theater and movies)

def: an area of activity where important things happen, especially in politics
ex: She was forced to the center of the political stage
ex: China is playing a leading role on the international stage

word: strain

def: pressure on someone or something because they have too much to do or manage, or something very difficult to deal with; the problems, worry, or anxiety that this produces

ex: I found it a strain having to concentrate for so long
ex: There are strains in the relationship between the two countries
ex: She was losing sleep over the pressure of her work
ex: stress-related illnesspressure or stress?It is common to say that someone is suffering from stress, while pressure may be the thing that causes stress
ex: nervous tensionstrain pressure on someone because they have too much to do or manage; the problems, worry, or anxiety that this produces:
ex: I found it a strain staying home with four children

ex: The rope broke under the strain

ex: The ground here cannot take the strain of a large building
ex: The cable has a 300lb

ex: a calf/groin/leg strain 
ex: muscle strain type of plant/animal/disease4[countable]

ex: a new strain of mosquitoes resistant to the poison

word: stuff

def: used to refer to a substance, material, group of objects, etc. when you do not know the name, when the name is not important, or when it is obvious what you are talking about

ex: This box is full of camping things

ex: What's all this Mrs
ex: I don't believe in all that stuff about ghosts

ex: The trip was magical, the stuff of dreams
ex: Let's see what stuff you're made of (= what sort of person you are)

word: tell

def: to give information to someone by speaking or writing
ex: tell something to somebody 
ex: He told the news to everyone he saw
ex: tell somebody something 
ex: He told everyone he saw the news
ex: Did she tell you her name?

ex: They've told us (that) they're not coming

ex: tell somebody + speech 
ex: I'm ready to go now, he told her
ex: Sit down, she said
ex: Anne said, Im tired
ex: Anne said (that) she was tired
ex: What did he say to you?You cannot use say about, but say something about is correct:
ex: I want to say something/a few words/a little about my family
ex: She didnt say what she intended to do
ex: Have you told him the news yet?It is often used with that clauses:
ex: Anne told me (that) she was tired
ex: Can you tell me when the movie starts?(BUT:
ex: Can you give me some information about the school?)Tell is also used when you are giving someone instructions:
ex: The doctor told me to stay in bed
ex: The doctor told me (that) I had to stay in bed
ex: The doctor said (that) I had to stay in bed

ex: tell somebody something 
ex: The advertisement told us very little about the product
ex: tell somebody how, where, etc 
ex: This gauge tells you how much fuel you have left

ex: The sound of his breathing told her (that) he was asleep

ex: tell somebody how, what, etc

ex: the theme from The Godfather4 (old-fashioned) 

def: a short piece of writing on a particular subject, done for school

def: the part of a sentence or clause that contains information that is not new to the reader or audience

-----

word: themselves

def: used when people or animals performing an action are also affected by it
ex: They seemed to be enjoying themselves
ex: The children were arguing amongst themselves
ex: They've bought themselves a new car

def: used to emphasize 
ex: They themselves had had a similar experience
ex: Don and Julie paid for it themselves

def: used instead of 
ex: There wasn't anyone who hadn't enjoyed themselves

-----

word: then

def: used to refer to a particular time in the past or future
ex: Life was harder then because neither of us had a job
ex: Things were very different back then
ex: She grew up in Zimbabwe, or Rhodesia as it then was
ex: I saw them at Christmas but haven't heard a thing since then
ex: I've been invited too, so I'll see you then
ex: There's a room free in Bob's house next week but you can stay with us until then
ex: Call again next week
ex: Just then (= at that moment) there was a knock at the door
ex: She left in 1984 and from then on he lived alone
ex: I took one look at the car and offered to buy it there and then/then and there (= immediately)

def: used to introduce the next item in a series of actions, events, instructions, etc.
ex: He drank a glass of whiskey, then another, and then another
ex: First cook the onions, then add the mushrooms
ex: We lived in France and then Italy before coming back to the United States
ex: This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making
ex: First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips
ex: Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine
ex: Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed
ex: Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities
ex: The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt
ex: As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away
ex: At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper
ex: The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls

def: used to show the logical result of a particular statement or situation
ex: If you miss that train then you'll have to get a taxi
ex: My wife got a job in Chicago
ex: You haven't done anything to upset me
ex: Why don't you rent a car? Then you'll be able to visit more of the area

def: used to introduce additional information
ex: She's been very busy at work and then there was all that trouble with her son

def: used to introduce a summary of something that has just been said
ex: These, then, are the main areas of concern

def: used to show the beginning or end of a conversation, statement, etc.
ex: Right then, where do you want the table to go? 
ex: I really have to go
ex: OK then, I think we've just about covered everything on the agenda

-----

word: theory

def: a formal set of ideas that is intended to explain why something happens or exists
ex: According to the theory of relativity, nothing can travel faster than light
ex: The debate is centered around two conflicting theories

def: the principles on which a particular subject is based
ex: the theory and practice of language teaching 
ex: literary theory3[countable] 
ex: theory (that) 

def: an opinion or idea that someone believes is true but that is not proved
ex: I have this theory that most people prefer being at work to being at home
ex: In this study, the empirical data do not support current theories
ex: New facts and observations test established theories
ex: The theory posits that some character types are better prepared for the challenges of being president
ex: The results of our experiment aligned very closely with that predicted by theory
ex: In economic theory, when there is more competition prices are lower
ex: Based on the theory developed in this paper, it is predicted that
ex: Although some purely theoretical work has been done, there is a need for empirical research
ex: The next section outlines the theoretical framework and reviews the prior literature
ex: These scientific hypotheses have to be logically and theoretically defensible

word: through

def: from one end or side of something or someone to the other
ex: The burglar got in through the window
ex: The bullet went straight through him
ex: Her knees had gone through (= made holes in) her jeans
ex: The sand ran through (= between) my fingers
ex: The path led through the trees to the river
ex: The doctor pushed his way through the crowd
ex: The Charles River flows through Boston
ex: see, hear, etc

def: to see, hear, etc. something from the other side of an object or a substance
ex: I couldn't hear their conversation through the wall
ex: He could just make out three people through the mist

def: from the beginning to the end of an activity, a situation, or a period of time
ex: The children are too young to sit through a concert
ex: He will not live through the night
ex: I'm halfway through (= reading) her second novel

def: past a barrier, stage, or test
ex: Go through this gate, and you'll see the house on your left
ex: He drove through a red light (= passed it when he should have stopped)
ex: First I have to get through the exams
ex: The bill had a difficult passage through Congress
ex: I'd never have gotten through it all (= a difficult situation) without you

def: until, and including
ex: We'll be in New York Tuesday through Friday

def: by means of; because of
ex: You can only achieve success through hard work
ex: It was through him (= as a result of his help) that I got the job
ex: The accident happened through no fault of mine

def: in or into every part of something
ex: They export their products to markets throughout the world

def: during the whole period of time of something
ex: The museum is open daily throughout the year

an assault/a raid (on somebody)	employ/use guerrilla tactics	conduct/wage biological/guerrilla warfare	fight/crush/defeat the rebels/the insurgency	suffer/inflict a crushing defeat	achieve/win a decisive victory	halt/stop the American/German advance	order/force a retreatfighting	join/serve in the Army/Navy/Air Force/Marines/Coast Guard/reserves	be/go/remain/serve on active duty	do/complete/return from a tour of duty	be sent to the front (line)	attack/strike/engage/defeat/kill/destroy the enemy	witness/see/report/be engaged in heavy fighting	call for/be met with armed resistance	come under heavy/machine-gun/mortar fire	fire a machine gun/mortar shells/rockets (at somebody/something)	shoot a rifle/a pistol/bullets/missiles	launch/fire a(n) cruise/ballistic/anti-tank missile	use biological/chemical/nuclear weapons	inflict/suffer/sustain heavy losses/casualties	be hit/killed by enemy/friendly/artillery fire	become/be held as/be taken as a prisoner of warcivilians in war	harm/kill/target/protect innocent/unarmed civilians	cause/avoid/limit/minimize civilian casualties/collateral damage	impose/enforce/lift a curfew	engage in/be a victim of ethnic cleansing	be sent to a concentration/an internment camp	accept/house/resettle/turn away refugees fleeing from war	fear/threaten military/violent reprisals	commit/be accused of war crimes/crimes against humanity/genocidemaking peace	make/bring/win/achieve/maintain/promote peace	call for/negotiate/broker/declare a ceasefire/a temporary truce	sign a ceasefire agreement	call for/bring/put an end to hostilities	demand/negotiate/accept the surrender of somebody/something	establish/send (in) a peacekeeping force	negotiate/conclude/ratify/sign/accept/reject/break/violate a peace treaty2[countable]

ex: Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds

ex: The building is currently being used as a warehouse
ex: You can't keep using your bad back as an excuse
ex: use something 

def: to take a particular amount of a liquid, substance, etc. in order to achieve or make something
ex: This type of heater uses a lot of electricity
ex: I hope you haven't used all the milk
ex: use something 

def: to say or write particular words or a particular type of language
ex: The poem uses simple language
ex: That's a word I never use
ex: You have to use the past tense
ex: use somebody (disapproving) 

def: to be kind, friendly, etc. to someone with the intention of getting an advantage for yourself from them
ex: Can't you see he's just using you for his own ends? 
ex: I felt used
ex: use (something) 

def: to take illegal drugs
ex: Most of the inmates have used drugs at some point in their lives
ex: She's been using since she was 13

word: use

def: the act of using something; the state of being used
ex: A ban was imposed on the use of chemical weapons
ex: The software is designed for use in schools
ex: I'm not sure that this is the most valuable use of my time
ex: The chapel was built in the 18th century and is still in use today
ex: The pool is for the use of members only

def: a purpose for which something is used; a way in which something is or can be used
ex: I'm sure you'll think of a use for it
ex: This chemical has a wide range of industrial uses
ex: use (of something) 

def: the right or opportunity to use something, for example something that belongs to someone else
ex: I have the use of the car this week

def: the ability to use your mind or body
ex: He lost the use of his legs (= became unable to walk) in an accident

-----

word: used

def: familiar with something because you do it or experience it often
ex: used to doing something 
ex: I'm not used to eating so much at lunchtime
ex: used to something 
ex: I found the job tiring at first but I soon got used to it
ex: I used to smoke, but I gave up a couple of years ago
ex: Were used to the noise from the traffic now
ex: Im used to getting up early
ex: Dont worryyoull soon get used to his sense of humor
ex: I didnt think I could ever get used to living in a big city after living in the country

-----

word: used

def: that has belonged to or been used by someone else before
ex: used carsCheck pronunciation: used

-----

word: used to

def: used to say that something happened continuously or frequently during a period in the past
ex: I used to live in London
ex: We used to go sailing on the lake in the summer
ex: I didn't use to like him much when we were in school
ex: You used to see a lot of her, didn't you? Grammarmodal verbsThe modal verbs are can, could, may, might, must, ought to, shall, should, will, and would
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results
ex: I used to smoke, but I gave up a couple of years ago
ex: Were used to the noise from the traffic now
ex: Im used to getting up early
ex: Dont worryyoull soon get used to his sense of humor
ex: I didnt think I could ever get used to living in a big city after living in the country
ex: I used to go there every Saturday
ex: Did she use to have long hair?Note that the correct spelling is use to, not used to

-----

def: that can help you to do or achieve what you want
ex: a useful gadget 
ex: useful (to do something) 
ex: It can be useful to write a short summary of your argument first
ex: useful (to somebody) 
ex: He might be useful to us
ex: useful (for something/for doing something) 
ex: These plants are particularly useful for brightening up shady areas
ex: Don't just sit watching TV make yourself useful! 
ex: This information could prove useful
ex: Your knowledge of German may come in useful (= be useful in a particular situation)
ex: Some products can be recycled at the end of their useful life

word: variation

def: a change, especially in the amount or level of something
ex: The dial records very slight variations in pressure
ex: Currency exchange rates are always subject to variation
ex: regional/seasonal variation (= depending on the region or time of year) AWL Collocationsvaryvary verbto be different from each other; to become different or to changeestimate, opinion, pricing, ratio, result rate, size
ex: Estimates vary because measurement techniques differ from study to study
ex: Spanish is spoken with an accent that varies considerably according to region
ex: The cost of cattle varies inversely with supply
ex: There are a wealth of resources on the World Wide Web, containing information with varying degrees of accuracy and reliability
ex: One predictor variable of early reading success is vocabulary knowledge
ex: In this study, age was measured as a continuous variable ranging from 18 to 70 years
ex: The categorical variables were gender and marital status
ex: There is considerable variation; what works for one patient does not necessarily work for another
ex: The area has spatial variations in rainfall, with the southern areas receiving more rainfall than central locations
ex: Considerable variability in all aspects of testing practices was evident
ex: Wild plant species usually have a great deal of genetic variability
ex: There is considerable variability within the group, with some students reading at grade level, and others demonstrating significant reading problems
ex: Fibers may be derived from paper, metal, nylon, and other materials having widely varied physical properties
ex: The judicial systems of the rest of the world are immensely varied
ex: Rainfall is highly variable, and the start and end of the two rainy seasons are unreliable
ex: variation (on something)

ex: variation (on something) (music)

ex: to listen to the weather see also weather forecast Topic CollocationsThe Weathergood weather	be bathed in/bask in/be blessed with/enjoy bright/brilliant/glorious sunshine	the sun shines/warms something/beats down (on something)	the sunshine breaks/streams through something	fluffy/wispy clouds drift across the sky	a gentle/light/stiff/cool/warm breeze blows in/comes in off the sea	the snow crunches beneath/under somebody's feet/bootsbad weather	thick/dark/storm clouds form/gather/roll in/cover the sky/block out the sun	the sky darkens/turns black	a fine mist hangs in the air	a dense/heavy/thick fog rolls in	the rain falls/comes down (in buckets/sheets)/pours down	snow falls/comes down/covers something/blankets something	the wind blows/whistles/howls/picks up/whips through something/sweeps across something	strong/gale-force winds blow/gust (up to 80 mph)	a storm is approaching/is moving inland/hits/strikes/rages	thunder rolls/rumbles/sounds	(forked/sheet) lightning strikes/hits/flashes	a (blinding/snow) blizzard hits/strikes/blows/rages	a tornado touches down/hits/strikes/destroys something/rips through something	forecast/expect/predict rain/snow/a category-four hurricane	rain pours (down)	get caught in/seek shelter from/escape the rain	be covered/shrouded in mist/a blanket of fog	be in for/brave/shelter from a/the storm	hear rolling/distant thunder	be battered/buffeted by strong winds	battle against/brave the elementsthe weather improves	the sun breaks through the clouds	the sky clears/brightens (up)/lightens (up)	the clouds part/clear	the rain stops/lets up/holds off	the wind dies down	the storm passes	the mist/fog lifts/clearsIdioms in all weathers

word: whatever

def: any or every; anything or everything

ex: Do whatever you like

ex: You should try an herbal remedy

def: used to say that you do not mind what you do, have, etc. and that anything is acceptable
ex: What would you like to do today? Oh, whatever is fine with me

word: when

ex: It's one of the few countries where people drive on the left

def: the place or situation in which
ex: We then moved to Chicago, where we lived for six years
