word: whereas

def: used to compare or contrast two facts
ex: Some of the studies show positive results, whereas others do not
ex: We thought she was arrogant, whereas in fact she was just very shy
ex: This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U
ex: One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet
ex: Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games
ex: The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites
ex: Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone
ex: On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone
ex: The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends
ex: When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics

def: used at the beginning of a sentence in an official document to mean because of the fact that

-----

word: wherever

def: in any place
ex: Sit wherever you like
ex: He comes from Boula,wherever that may be (= I don't know where it is)

def: in all places that
ex: Wherever she goes, there are crowds of people waiting to see her

def: in all cases that
ex: Use whole grain breakfast cereals wherever possible

-----

word: whether

def: used to express a doubt or choice between two possibilities
ex: He seemed undecided whether to go or stay
ex: It remains to be seen whether or not this idea can be put into practice
ex: I asked him whether he had done it all himself or whether someone had helped him
ex: I'll see whether she's at home (= or not at home)
ex: It's doubtful whether there'll be any seats left
ex: She asked if/whether I wanted a drink
ex: We didnt know if/whether we should write or phone

def: used to show that something is true in either of two cases
ex: You are entitled to a free gift whether you accept our offer of insurance or not 
ex: I'm going whether you like it or not
ex: Whether or not we're successful, we can be sure that we did our best

-----

word: which

def: used in questions to ask someone to be exact about one or more people or things from a limited number
ex: Which is better exerciseswimming or tennis? 
ex: Which of the applicants got the job? 
ex: Which of the patients have recovered? 
ex: Which way is the wind blowing? compare what2 

def: used to give more information about something, or make a comment on something
ex: His best movie, which won several awards, was about the life of Gandhi
ex: We had to wait 16 hours for our plane, which was really annoying
ex: Your claim should succeed,in which case the damages will be substantial

def: used to be exact about the thing or things that you mean
ex: It was a crisis for which she was totally unprepared
ex: Houses that overlook the lake cost more
ex: It was a crisis that she was totally unprepared for

-----

word: while

def: during the time that something is happening
ex: We must have been robbed while we were asleep
ex: Her parents died while she was still in school
ex: While I was waiting at the bus stop, three buses went by in the opposite direction

def: at the same time as something else is happening
ex: You can go swimming while I'm having lunch
ex: shoes repaired while you wait3

def: used to contrast two things
ex: While Tom's very good at science, his brother is absolutely hopeless
ex: Some people work better to music while others do not
ex: This survey highlights a number of differences in the way that teenage boys and girls in the U
ex: One of the main differences between the girls and the boys who took part in the research was the way in which they use the Internet
ex: Unlike the girls, who use the Internet mainly to keep in touch with friends, the boys questioned in this survey tend to use the Internet for playing computer games
ex: The girls differ from the boys in that they tend to spend more time keeping in touch with friends on the telephone or on social networking websites
ex: Compared with the boys, the girls spend much more time chatting to friends on the telephone
ex: On average, the girls spend four hours a week chatting to friends on the phone
ex: The boys prefer competitive sports and computer games, whereas/while the girls seem to enjoy more cooperative activities, such as shopping with friends
ex: When the girls go shopping, they mainly buy clothes and cosmetics

def: although; despite the fact that
ex: While I am willing to help, I do not have much time available
ex: While the movie is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing work of art
ex: It can be argued that the movie is too long
ex: The movie is undoubtedly too long
ex: Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling
ex: Critics are wrong to argue that the movie's plot is too complicated
ex: It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent movie
ex: It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre

-----

word: whisper

def: to speak very quietly to someone so that other people cannot hear what you are saying
ex: Don't you know it's rude to whisper? 
ex: whisper about something 
ex: What are you two whispering about? 
ex: + speech 
ex: Can you meet me tonight? he whispered
ex: whisper something (to somebody) 
ex: She leaned over and whispered something in his ear
ex: whisper (to somebody) that 
ex: He whispered to me that he was afraid
ex: whisper that 
ex: it is whispered that 

def: to say or suggest something about someone or something in a private or secret way
ex: It was whispered that he would soon die and he did
ex: (+ adv

def: to make a soft, quiet sound
ex: A warm breeze whispered through the trees

-----

word: whistle

def: a small metal or plastic tube that you blow to make a loud, high sound, used to attract attention or as a signal
ex: The referee finally blew the whistle to stop the game

def: the sound made by blowing a 
ex: He scored the winning goal just seconds before the final whistle

def: the sound that you make by forcing your breath out when your lips are closed
ex: a shrill whistle 
ex: He gave a low long whistle of surprise

def: the high, loud sound produced by air or steam being forced through a small opening, or by something moving quickly through the air
ex: the whistle of a boiling kettle 
ex: the whistle of a bullet5

def: a piece of equipment that makes a high, loud sound when air or steam is forced through it
ex: The train whistle blew as we left the station
ex: a factory whistleIdioms as clean as a whistle (informal)

-----

word: white

def: having the color of fresh snow or of milk
ex: a crisp white shirt 
ex: white bread 
ex: a set of perfect white teeth 
ex: His hair was as white as snow
ex: The horse was almost pure white in color

def: belonging to or connected with a race of people who have pale skin
ex: white middle-class families 
ex: She writes about her experiences as a black girl in a predominantly white city

def: pale because of emotion or illness
ex: white with shock 
ex: She went white as a sheet when she heard the news

word: who

def: used in questions to ask about the name, identity, or function of one or more people
ex: Who is that woman? 
ex: I wonder who that letter was from
ex: Who are you calling? 
ex: Who's the money for?2

def: used to show which person or people you mean
ex: The people who called yesterday want to buy the house
ex: The people who we met on vacation have sent us a card

def: used to give more information about someone
ex: Mrs
ex: And then Mary, who we had been talking about earlier, walked in

-----

word: whoever

def: the person or people who; any person who
ex: Whoever says that is a liar
ex: Send it to whoever is in charge of sales

def: used to say that it does not matter who, since the result will be the same
ex: Come out of there, whoever you are
ex: I don't want to see them, whoever they are

def: used in questions to mean who, expressing surprise
ex: Whoever heard of such a thing!Check pronunciation: whoever

-----

word: whole

def: full; complete
ex: He spent the whole day writing
ex: We drank a whole bottle each
ex: The whole country (= all the people in it) mourned her death
ex: Let's forget the whole thing
ex: She wasn't telling the whole truth

def: used to emphasize how large or important something is
ex: We offer a whole variety of weekend breaks
ex: I can't afford itthat's the whole point

def: not broken or damaged
ex: Owls usually swallow their prey whole (= without chewing it)
ex: Cut the apple into quarters
ex: Two halves make a whole
ex: Ive been waiting here for a whole hour
ex: Half (of) the work is already finished
ex: They spent half the time looking for a parking space
ex: Her house is half a mile down the road
ex: I waited for half an hour I waited for a half an hour
ex: This meal is only half cooked

-----

word: whom

def: used instead of who as the object of a verb or preposition
ex: Whom did they invite? 
ex: To whom should I write? 
ex: The author whom you criticized in your review has written a reply
ex: Her mother, in whom she confided, said she would support her unconditionally
ex: Who did you invite to the party?Whom is used as the pronoun after prepositions in written English and formal spoken English:
ex: To whom should I address the letter? 
ex: He asked me with whom I had discussed it
ex: Who should I address the letter to? 
ex: He asked me who I had discussed it with
ex: The family (who/that/whom) I met at the airport were very kind
ex: Our doctor, whom we all liked very much, retired last week

-----

word: whose

def: used in questions to ask who something belongs to
ex: Whose house is that? 
ex: I wonder whose this is

def: used to say which person or thing you mean
ex: He's a man whose opinion I respect
ex: It's the house whose door is painted red

def: used to give more information about a person or thing
ex: Isaac, whose brother he was, had heard the joke before

-----

word: why

def: used in questions to ask the reason for or purpose of something
ex: Why were you late? 
ex: Tell me why you did it
ex: I would like you to go
ex: Why oh why do people keep leaving the door open?2

def: used in questions to suggest that it is not necessary to do something
ex: Why get upset just because you got one bad grade? 
ex: Why bother to write? We'll see him tomorrow

def: used to give or talk about a reason
ex: That's why I left so early
ex: I know you did itI just want to know why
ex: The reason why the injection needs repeating every year is that the virus changes

word: wide

def: measuring a lot from one side to the other
ex: a wide river 
ex: Sam has a wide mouth

ex: Her face broke into a wide grin

ex: How wide is that stream? 
ex: It's about 2 yards wide
ex: The road was just wide enough for two vehicles to pass

ex: Her music appeals to a wide audience
ex: Jenny has a wide circle of friends
ex: a manager with wide experience of industry 
ex: It's the best job in the whole wide world
ex: The incident has received wide coverage in the press
ex: The festival attracts people from a wide area

def: very big
ex: There are wide variations in prices

def: general; not only looking at details
ex: the wider aims of the project 
ex: We are talking about education in its widest sense

def: fully open
ex: She stared at him with wide eyes
ex: wide (of something) 

def: far from the point aimed at
ex: Her shot was wide (of the target)

def: happening or existing in the whole of a country, etc.
ex: a nationwide search 
ex: We need to act on an industry-wide scale
ex: mouth)
ex: a broad river 
ex: a broad stretch of meadowland	Both wide and broad can be used to describe something that includes a large variety of different people or things:

word: will

def: used for talking about or predicting the future
ex: You'll be in time if you hurry

ex: He wouldn't comehe said he was too busy
ex: We said we would keep them

def: used for asking someone to do something
ex: Will you send this letter for me, please? 
ex: You'll water the plants while I'm away, won't you? 
ex: I asked him if he wouldn't mind calling later

def: used for ordering someone to do something
ex: You'll do it this minute! 
ex: Will you be quiet!5

def: used for stating what you think is probably true
ex: That'll be the doctor now
ex: You'll have had dinner already, I suppose

def: used for stating what is generally true
ex: If it's made of wood it will float
ex: Engines won't run without lubricants

def: used for stating what is true or possible in a particular case
ex: This jar will hold a pint
ex: The door won't open!8

def: used for talking about habits
ex: She'll listen to music, alone in her room, for hours

ex: She will try and visit tomorrow

ex: You shouldn't invite Mary

ex: Ill (= I will) be lateand
ex: Youll (= you will) have your turn next

word: within

def: before a particular period of time has passed; during a particular period of time
ex: You should receive a reply within seven days
ex: The ambulance arrived within minutes of the call being made
ex: Two elections were held within the space of a year

def: not further than a particular distance from something
ex: a house within a mile of the station 
ex: Is it within walking distance?3

def: inside the range or limits of something
ex: That question is not within the scope of this talk
ex: We are now within range of enemy fire
ex: He finds it hard to live within his income (= without spending more than he earns)

def: inside something or someone
ex: The noise seems to be coming from within the building
ex: There is discontent within the farming industry
ex: Despite her grief, she found a hidden strength within herself

-----

word: without

def: not having, experiencing, or showing something
ex: They had gone two days without food
ex: He found the place without difficulty
ex: She spoke without much enthusiasm

def: not in the company of someone
ex: Don't go without me

def: not using or taking something
ex: Can you see without your glasses? 
ex: Don't go out without your coat

def: not doing the action mentioned
ex: without doing something 
ex: He left without saying goodbye
ex: You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs
ex: Without wanting to criticize, I think you could have done better
ex: without somebody doing something 
ex: The party was planned without her knowing anything about it

ex: Remembernot a word to (= don't tell) Peter about any of this
ex: He never breathed a word of this to me

ex: The word is they split up

ex: Do not write more than 200 words
ex: He uses a lot of long words

ex: Old man is a slang term for father

ex: work in somebody's favor

ex: work something

ex: He stared at me in horror, his mouth working

word: would

def: used as the past form of 
ex: He said he would be here at eight o'clock (= His words were: I will be there at eight o'clock
ex: She asked if I would help
ex: They told me that they probably wouldn't come

def: used for talking about the result of an event that you imagine
ex: She'd look better with shorter hair
ex: If you went to see him, he would be delighted
ex: Hurry up! It would be a shame to miss the beginning of the play
ex: She'd be a fool to accept it (= if she accepted)

def: used for describing a possible action or event that did not in fact happen, because something else did not happen first
ex: If I had seen the advertisement in time I would have applied for the job
ex: They would never have met if she hadn't gone to Emma's party
ex: so that/in order that somebody/something would 

def: used for saying why someone does something
ex: She burned the letters so that her husband would never read them
ex: wish (that) somebody/something would 

def: used for saying what you want to happen
ex: I wish you'd be quiet for a minute

def: used to show that someone or something was not willing or refused to do something
ex: She wouldn't change it, even though she knew it was wrong
ex: My car wouldn't start this morning

def: used to ask someone politely to do something
ex: Would you mind leaving us alone for a few minutes? 
ex: Would you open the door for me, please?8

def: used in polite offers or invitations
ex: Would you like a sandwich? 
ex: Would you have dinner with me on Friday?9 
ex: would like, love, hate, prefer, etc
ex: would rather do something/somebody did something 

def: used to say what you like, love, hate, etc.
ex: I'd love some coffee
ex: I'd be only too glad to help
ex: I'd hate you to think I was criticizing you
ex: I'd rather come with you
ex: I'd rather you came with us
ex: would imagine, say, think, etc

def: used to give opinions that you are not certain about
ex: I would imagine the job will take about two days
ex: I'd say he was about fifty

def: used to give advice
ex: I wouldn't have any more to drink,if I were you

def: used for talking about things that often happened in the past
ex: When my parents were away, my grandmother would take care of me
ex: He'd always be the first to offer to help

def: used for talking about behavior that you think is typical
ex: She said it was your fault
ex: would that (literary) 

def: used to express a strong wish
ex: Would that he had lived to see it
ex: He can speak three languages
ex: She will try and visit tomorrow
ex: You must find a job
ex: You ought to stop smoking
ex: I used to smoke, but I quit two years ago
ex: Can I invite Mary? 
ex: Should I have invited Mary?Negative sentences are formed with not or the short form -nt and do not use do/does or did:
ex: You shouldn't invite Mary
ex: The error will not have affected our results
ex: You should take the baby to the doctors
ex: I ought to give up smoking
ex: Should we call the doctor?Had better can also be used to say what is the best thing to do in a situation that is happening now:
ex: Wed better hurry or well miss the train
ex: She should have asked for some help
ex: You ought to have been more careful
ex: You shouldnt drive so fast
ex: Im sorry, I shouldnt have lost my temper

ex: The nurse wrapped a bandage tightly around my ankle

def: to cause text to be carried over to a new line automatically as you reach the end of the previous line; to be carried over in this way
ex: wrap something (around) 
ex: How can I wrap the text? 
ex: wrap (around) 
ex: The text wraps around if it is too long to fit the screen

word: write

def: to make letters or numbers on a surface, especially using a pen or a pencil
ex: In some countries children don't start learning to read and write until they are six
ex: write in/on/with something 
ex: Please write in pen on both sides of the paper
ex: I haven't got anything to write with
ex: write something 
ex: Write your name at the top of the paper
ex: The teacher wrote the answers on the board
ex: The b had been wrongly written as a d

def: to produce something in written form so that people can read, perform, or use it, etc.
ex: write something 
ex: to write a novel/a song/an essay/a computer program, etc
ex: Who was The Grapes of Wrath written by? 
ex: Which opera did Verdi write first? 
ex: write something about/on something 
ex: He hopes to write a book about his experiences one day
ex: She had to write a report on the project
ex: write (about something) 
ex: I wanted to travel and then write about it
ex: He writes for the The New Yorker
ex: No decision has been made at the time of writing
ex: write somebody something 
ex: She wrote him several poems

def: to put information, a message of good wishes, etc. in a letter and send it to someone
ex: Bye! Don't forget to write
ex: Can you write and confirm your reservation? 
ex: I'm writing to inquire about language classes 
ex: write to somebody 
ex: She wrote to him in France
ex: write something (to somebody) 
ex: I wrote a letter to the Publicity Department
ex: write somebody something 
ex: I wrote the Publicity Department a letter
ex: write that 
ex: She wrote that they were all fine
ex: write somebody 
ex: Write me while you're away
ex: write somebody that 
ex: He wrote me that he would be arriving Monday
ex: write doing something 
ex: They wrote thanking us for the present

def: to state the information or the words mentioned
ex: write that 
ex: In his latest book he writes that the theory has since been disproved
ex: write of something 
ex: Ancient historians wrote of a lost continent beneath the ocean
ex: + speech 
ex: Of all my books, wrote Dickens, I like this the best

def: to put information in the appropriate places on a check or other form
ex: write something (out) 
ex: to write out a check 
ex: write somebody (out) something 
ex: I'll write you a receipt
ex: The doctor wrote her a prescription for more antibiotics
ex: write (something) to/onto something 

def: to record data in the memory of a computer
ex: An error was reported when he tried to write data to the file for the first time

def: to work correctly or in the way mentioned
ex: This pen won't write

word: wrong

def: not right or correct
ex: I got all the answers wrong
ex: He was driving on the wrong side of the road
ex: Sorry, I must have dialed the wrong number
ex: You're holding the camera the wrong way up! 
ex: That picture is the wrong way around

ex: I think she lives at number 44, but I could be wrong

ex: You were wrong about Tom; he's not married after all
ex: wrong (to do something) 
ex: We were wrong to assume that she'd agree
ex: She would prove him wrong (= prove that he was wrong) whatever happened
ex: You think you've beaten me but that's where you're wrong
ex: Correct me if I'm wrong (= I may be wrong) but didn't you say you two knew each other? causing problems3[not before noun]

ex: What's wrong? Oh, nothing

ex: There's something wrong with the printer
ex: The doctor could find nothing wrong with him
ex: Ihave something wrong with my foot

def: not suitable, right or what you need
ex: wrong (something) (for something) 
ex: He's the wrong person for the job
ex: wrong (something to do) 
ex: I realized that it was the wrong thing to say
ex: We don't want this document falling into the wrong hands
ex: It was his bad luck to be in the wrong place at the wrong time (= so that he got involved in trouble without intending to)

ex: wrong with something/with doing something 
ex: What's wrong with eating meat? 
ex: wrong that 
ex: It is wrong that he should not be punished for what he did

ex: My name was spelled wrong
ex: Im afraid you guessed wrong
ex: He was wrongly targeted by the media
ex: She guessed wrongly that he was a teacher

word: year

def: the period from January 1 to December 31, that is 365 or 366 days, divided into 12 months
ex: in the year 1865 
ex: I lost my job earlier this year
ex: Elections take place every year
ex: The museum is open all year round (= during the whole year)

def: a period of 12 months, measured from any particular time
ex: It's exactly a year since I started working here
ex: She gave up teaching three years ago
ex: in the first year of their marriage 
ex: the prewar/war/postwar years (= the period before/during/after the war) 
ex: I have happy memories of my years in Paris (= the time I spent there)

def: a period of 12 months connected with a particular activity
ex: the academic/school year 
ex: the tax year see also fiscal year4 [countable, usually plural] 

def: age; time of life

ex: That's the best movie I've seen in years
ex: We've had a lot of fun over the years

word: yes

def: used to answer a question and say that something is correct or true
ex: Is this your car? Yes, it is
ex: Are you coming? Yes or no?2

def: used to show that you agree with what has been said
ex: I enjoyed her latest novel
ex: It's an excellent hotel

def: used to disagree with something negative that someone has just said
ex: I've never met her before

def: used to agree to a request or to give permission
ex: Dad, can I borrow the car? Yes, but be careful
ex: We're hoping that they will say yes to our proposals

def: used to accept an offer or invitation
ex: Would you like a drink? Yes, please/thanks

def: used for asking someone what they want
ex: Yes? How can I help you?7

def: used for replying politely when someone calls you
ex: Waiter! Yes, sir?8

def: used to show that you have just remembered something
ex: Where did I put the keys? Oh, yesin my pocket!9

def: used to encourage someone to continue speaking
ex: I'm going to Paris this weekend

def: used to show that you do not believe what someone has said
ex: Sorry I'm latethe bus didn't come

def: used to emphasize what you have just said
ex: Mrs

def: used to show that you are excited or extremely pleased about something that you have done or something that has happened
ex: They've scored another goal

def: used to show that you are impatient or irritated about something
ex: Hurry upit's late

word: yet

def: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen
ex: I haven't received a letter from him yet
ex: I didn't receive a letter from him yet
ex: Are you ready? No, not yet
ex: We have yet to decide what action to take (= We have not decided what action to take)

def: now; as soon as this
ex: Don't go yet
ex: We don't need to start yet

def: from now until the period of time mentioned has passed
ex: He'll be busy for ages yet
ex: They won't arrive for at least two hours yet
ex: could, might, may, etc

def: used to say that something could, might, etc. happen in the future, even though it seems unlikely
ex: We may win yet
ex: She could yet surprise us all
ex: the best, longest, etc

def: the best, longest, etc. thing of its kind made, produced, written, etc. until now/then
ex: the most comprehensive study yet of his music 
ex: It was the highest building yet constructed
ex: yet another/more 
ex: yet again 

def: used to emphasize an increase in number or amount or the number of times something happens
ex: snow, snow and yet more snow 
ex: yet another diet book 
ex: Prices were cut yet again (= once more, after many other times)
ex: yet worse, more importantly, etc

def: used to emphasize an increase in the degree of something (= how bad, important, etc. it is)
ex: a recent and yet more improbable theoryIdioms as yet

word: you

def: used as the subject or object of a verb or after a preposition to refer to the person or people being spoken or written to
ex: You said you knew the way
ex: I thought she told you
ex: Can I sit next to you? 
ex: I don't think that hairstyle is you (= it doesn't suit your appearance or personality)

def: used with nouns and adjectives to speak to someone directly
ex: You girls, stop talking! 
ex: You stupid idiot!3

def: used for referring to people in general
ex: You learn a language better if you visit the country where it is spoken
ex: It's a friendly place  people come up to you in the street and start talking

word: young

def: having lived or existed for only a short time; not fully developed
ex: young babies 
ex: a young country 
ex: Caterpillars eat the young leaves of this plant
ex: a young wine 
ex: The night is still young (= it has only just started)

def: not yet old; not as old as others
ex: young people 
ex: talented young football players 
ex: I am the youngest of four sisters
ex: In his younger days he played baseball for the Mets
ex: I met the young Bill Clinton at Georgetown
ex: Her grandchildren keep her young
ex: My son is thirteen, but he's young for his age (= not as developed as other boys of the same age)
ex: They married young (= at an early age)
ex: My mother died young

def: suitable or appropriate for young people
ex: young fashion 
ex: The clothes she wears are much too young for her

def: consisting of young people or young children; with a low average age
ex: They have a young family
ex: a young audience5 
ex: young man/lady 

def: used to show that you are angry or annoyed with a particular young person
ex: I think you owe me an apology, young lady!6 the younger 

def: used before or after a person's name to distinguish them from an older relative
ex: the younger Kennedy (formal) 
ex: William Pitt the Younger compare elder, juniorIdioms be getting younger (informal)

word: your

def: of or belonging to the person or people being spoken or written to
ex: I like your dress
ex: Excuse me, is this your seat? 
ex: The bank is on your right

def: of or belonging to people in general
ex: Dentists advise you to have your teeth checked every six months
ex: In Japan you are taught great respect for your elders

ex: This is your typical dive bar
ex: You and your bright ideas!4Your

ex: Your Majesty 
ex: Your ExcellencyCheck pronunciation: your

word: yourself

ex: Did you hurt yourself?

ex: Do it yourselfI don't have time

def: you
ex: We sell a lot of these to people like yourself
ex: And yourself, he replied, How are you? Yourself is sometimes used in this way as a polite way of saying you, but some people think this is incorrect

word: zone

def: an area or a region with a particular feature or use
ex: a security/demilitarized, etc
ex: an earthquake/danger, etc
ex: a pedestrian zone (= where vehicles may not go) see also no-fly zone, time zone, twilight2

def: one of the areas that a larger area is divided into for the purpose of organization
ex: postal charges to countries in zone 23

def: an area or a part of an object, especially one that is different from its surroundings
ex: When the needle enters the red zone, the engine is too hot
ex: the erogenous zones of the body see also crumple zone4

def: one of the parts that the earth's surface is divided into by imaginary lines that are parallel to the 
ex: the northern/southern temperate zoneIdioms in the zone (informal)
